loans.name: Otuma Ole

texts.en:
Otuma ole N. is 32-years-old. He is married to Kimanyesho N. and they have one child in school. 

Otuma is a wheat farmer and who has farmed his own piece of land for the last six years.

He learned about KADET from marketing done by Kadet staff in his area This will be his second loan. He is planning to plant twenty acres of wheat which does very well in this area. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to hire more land for farming to increase his wheat production.

His dream is to buy a bigger piece of land where he can be a large-scale farmer and plant more wheat for commercial purposes, and to own his own farm machinery.

loans.use: To enlarge his wheat farm

loans.name: Ndiack

texts.fr: NDiack N. est une femme de  30 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de DIAMAKHEUL depuis 3 ans et y a reçu 6 fois de suite de crédit qu'elle a toujours bien gérés et remboursés à temps. Elle fait de l'embouche ovine et son nouveau prêt lui permettra d'acheter 5 paires de moutons qu'elle va engraisser pendant au moins 4 mois pour aller ensuite revendre au niveau des marchés hebdomadaires de sa localité. Par ailleurs elle mène une activité parallèle qui consiste la vente de denrées alimentaires. Son objectif est de soutenir son mari dans la prise en charge des différentes dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
Ndiack N., aged 30, is married and the mother of five children. She has been a member of the credit association of Diamakheul for three years and was granted six consecutive loans which she always managed well and repaid on schedule. Ndiack breeds cattle. This new loan will enable her to buy 5 couples of sheep. She will fatten them for at least four months and then sell them at the weekly trade fair of her village. At the same time she runs a grocery store. Her aim is to help her husband to provide for the family.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her working capital and buy sheep

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 22-year-old single man living with his parents. In 2009, this young man decided to start his own business; he opened a coffee shop, also serving Nargile, a special Lebanese tobacco very famous with the Lebanese people. The clients visit his café to have a good time. During this year, he has been able to attract a good number of clients and so a good profit. Therefore, he became able to help his father in the household. 

Today, Ali is requesting to borrow $1,200 to buy merchandise such as coffee and charcoal to meet the requirements of his customers, especially before the coming summer season.

loans.use: To buy merchandise such as coffee and charcoal.

loans.name: Martine Alex

texts.en:
Alex Martine S. is 28-years-old. He and his wife Mareen have one child in school. 

Alex is a wheat farmer who has farmed his own piece of land for the last four years.

He learned about KADET from marketing done by Kadet staff in his area. This will be his third loan. He plans to plant twenty acres of wheat, which does very well in this area. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to lease more land for farming to increase his wheat output.

Alex's dream is that he will be able to buy a bigger piece of land and do wheat farming on a larger scale. He is hard working and, with the right resources at his disposal, he believes he can achieve a lot.

loans.use: To plant twenty acres of wheat.

loans.name: Ghulam Rasool Group

texts.en: Afghan Gul is a member of the G. Rasool group. She lives in the 1st district of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is 40 years old and married with five children. She is a hard-working woman who has a quilt-sewing business with which she supports her family. She sews different kinds of quilts — especially ones she makes for Afghan brides. She hopes to grow her business and will use the loan to purchase cloth and different kinds of thread. She is grateful to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To grow her quilt-sewing business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy palm nuts

loans.name: Desi

texts.en:
Desi is a 41-year-old married woman who lives with her husband and two children. She has one daughter and one son. Desi is a hard-working woman.

Desi has been managing a food production business for the past two years. Her husband helps her to run this business. They are very close and work well together.

Desi has asked for a loan of 35,000 LKR from BRAC to improve her and her husband's business. She is grateful to BRAC Sri Lanka because of the financial support it provides to her.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To purchase materials for food production

loans.name: Milka

texts.en:
Milka J. T. is a 30-year-old lady who is married to Abraham T.. They have three children. She lives in Kaiboi, where she does tea farming and plants short seasonal crops like maize and beans. She also practices dairy farming and sells the milk to Kenya Cooperative Creameries, a milk-processing factory in Kenya.  

Milka was introduced to KADET by a women's group that consisted of some of her customers. She has applied for a loan, which she will use to prepare her 5 acres for planting maize and beans, to start poultry farming and to buy two more dairy cows.

Milka plans to become independent and generate more income from her different businesses so that she can pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To prepare her 5 acres for planting maize and beans and to start poultry farming

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy weed-killers and peanut seeds

loans.name: Kinyugunyu Turibamwe, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
K. Scovia is a friendly and very hardworking single lady with several orphans she takes care of.

Scovia’s business story began way back in 2007. She started a tailoring business in Kyinyugunyu trading centre, Ibanda district, and this earns her a profit of seventy thousand shillings on a monthly basis.

This loan is to help Scovia purchase more stock of good-quality materials that are eye-catching to bring customers into her business. With that she will be able to realize more sales and profits that will trigger her development economically, and enable her to meet the day-to-day life and general welfare of her family.

loans.use: To purchase more good-quality materials

loans.name: Hasmik

texts.en:
Hasmik is a 41-year-old married woman and mother of 2 dependent children. She has run a tailoring business, from her home, since 1998. She offers all sewing services in addition to clothes repairing services to her customers. She is known as a very active worker in her surrounding area. 

Today, Hasmik is requesting to borrow $1,200 to buy new textiles and to have maintenance needed for the sewing machine to be able to deliver her services faster because of the reparation. She's certain that she will offer her services with greater speed and make new products as a result of the loan requested.

loans.use: To buy new textiles and complete maintenance needed for the sewing machine.

loans.name: Dominic Kitipa

texts.en:
Dominic Kitipa N. is 26 years old. He is married to Nongishu N., and he is a father of one child, who is in school. 

Dominic is a farmer, and he has been farming on his own piece of land for the last six years.
  
He learned about KADET from a friend who is already KADET registered client. This will be his second loan. He is planning to plant 20 acres of wheat, which has proved to do very well in this area, and keep some sheep for fattening to sell later. With the profit he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to rent more land for farming to increase his wheat production. The area has a favorable climate for wheat farming, making him consider wheat farming only.

His future dream is that he will be able to buy a bigger piece of land for planting more wheat for commercial purpose and be the leading farmer in his area.

loans.use: To prepare land for wheat farming

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy groundnut seeds

loans.name: Hèrèdiya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Hèrèdiya sont toutes mariées dans des familles monogames. Elles ont en moyenne 44 ans et 5 enfants. Elles habitent  toutes  à Farabougou, village de la Commune Rurale de Téssérèla  (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, mariage et de voisinage. 
Les membres du groupe font le commerce d’arachide, d’habits, de poissons séchés et de calebasses. 
Le besoin d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les incita à s’organiser et à intégrer le programme crédit  de Soro Yiriwaso avec lequel, elles sont à leur 1er  prêt solidaire. 
Madame Alimata Sangaré veut utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 5 sacs d’arachide auprès des producteurs. Elle s’approvisionne à N’gassola,  à Tissala et à Téssérèla.  Elle revend son  arachide à domicile, en ambulant dans les villages voisins et dans  les foires de N’gassola et Téssérèla. Elle vend au comptant, en détail et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes, de femmes et d’enfants.  
Alimata espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 22.500FCFA qui sera utilisé pour, rembourser son prêt, contribuer à  certaines dépenses familiales, participer aux évènements sociaux (mariages, baptêmes et funérailles) et augmenter son fonds de commerce. 
Son ambition est de pérenniser son commerce à travers l’augmentation du fonds de commerce et posséder une charrette et un âne pour faciliter ses déplacements et le transport de ses marchandises.
texts.en:
The members of Hèrèdiya Group are all married women living in monogamous families. On average, they are 44 years old and have five children. They all live in Farabougou, a village located in the rural municipality of Téssérèla (fourth administrative region of Mali). They know each other through ties of kinship, marriage and neighborhood. The group members are businesswomen selling groundnuts, clothes, dried fish and calabashes. The urge to increase their working capital led them to create a team and join the credit program of Soro Yiriwaso. This is their first solidarity loan. Mrs Alimata Sangaré wants to use her loan to buy 5 sacks of groundnuts from the producers in N'gassola, Tissala and Téssérèla. She will sell the groundnuts from her home and by hawking in the nearby villages and at the trade fairs in N'gassola and Téssérèla. She retails, for cash and credit, to a clientele made up of men, women and children. Alimata expects to make a monthly profit of 22,500 CFA francs which she will use to repay her loan, contribute to some household expenses, participate in social events (weddings, baptisms and funerals) and increase her working capital. Her ambition is to perpetuate her business through sufficient working capital and own a cart and a donkey for her travelling and transportation needs.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy groundnuts

loans.name: Priscilla

texts.en:
Priscilla B. is a very strong-minded woman and she notes that she works hard to better her life. Despite hardships brought about by poverty, Priscilla remains strong and dedicated in her pursuit to improve her family’s standard of living. What motivates her all day is her aspiration to give her family a brighter future. 

To make a good living, Priscilla is a soft drinks dealer in her community. She has been in this business for nine years. She joined ASHI, a micro-finance institution and Kiva partner in the Philippines, in 2007. During the course of her membership, Priscilla has been a good performer: valued for her attendance at center meetings, repayments and business. She is now applying for her fourth loan, this time for 25,000 Philippine pesos, to obtain additional inventory of soft drinks. She is positive that with access to additional working capital through ASHI and Kiva, her dreams of an expanded business will be achieved.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory of soft drinks

loans.name: Bakyala Kwekulakulana, Lugazi Group

texts.en:
She has been plying her business of secondhand clothing in Ajjija, Lugazi for the last eight years. With this business, 42-year-old S. Aminah has sustained herself and her family of nine children. All her children are in high institutions of learning. 

Before she fully ventured into the business of secondhand clothing, Aminah was preoccupied with farming. She still does some farming to supplement her minimal earnings.

Aminah mostly sells children’s and women’s clothing and her clients have mostly been women from the locality she operates from. Her good human and customer relationship skills have lent that much needed countenance as she operates her business. 

In general terms, the problem of inadequate capital has been Aminah’s main undoing throughout these years of operation. With this loan, Amina is optimistic that her  business will make headway. She is looking at buying more secondhand clothing to sell to her ever-increasing clientele.

loans.use: To purchase more secondhand garments like trousers, shirts, jackets and vests

loans.name: Hawa

texts.fr:
Madame Hawa Dembélé est âgée de 52 ans, mariée et mère de  7 enfants. Elle vit avec son mari dans une famille nucléaire dans le quartier Darsalam de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ayant abandonné l’école  en classe de 5ème   année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien),  elle s’intéressa  alors aux activités génératrices de revenus auprès de sa mère. Hawa opta pour la préparation et la vente de boissons non alcoolisées telles les jus de fruits.  Elle  jouit d’une grande  clientèle et  notoriété.
Pour faire son jus elle utilise 2kg de  sucre, 6 sachets de poudre de jus grand format et  6 sachets de sucre de la  valine, le tout est mis dans un seau de 15litres d’eau.
Dans le souci d’avoir un nouvel équipement afin de faire face à la demande clientèle, elle fait recours à  Soro Yiriwaso.
Après 3 prêts solidaires et 2 prêts individuels tous correctement bien remboursés, elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel qui sera  utilisé pour acheter, 1  réfrigérateur   sur place à Ségou.
Madame Hawa Dembélé vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 50 000FCFA,  grâce auquel elle payera les frais scolaires des enfants. 
Son ambition est de diversifier son activité en menant la vente de calebasses.
texts.en:
Mrs Hawa Dembélé is 52 years old, married and mother to seven children. She lives with her husband in a nuclear family in the Darsalam district of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). When she left school in 5th grade (a fundamental year in the Mali education system) she started to get interested in revenue-generating activities with her mother. Hawa opted for the preparation and sale of soft drinks, such as fruit juices. She enjoys a large customer base and a good reputation. In order to make her juice she uses 2kg of sugar, six large sachets of juice powder and six sachets of valine sugar. All this is placed in a bucket of 15 litres of water. As she needs to have new equipment in order to cope with customer demand, she turned to Soro Yiriwaso. Having already had three group loans and two individual loans, all of which were repaid on time, she is now on her third individual loan, which will be used to buy a refrigerator locally in Ségou. Mrs. Hawa Dembélé sells for cash and on credit to a customer base made up of men and women. With this loan she is planning to make a monthly profit of 50,000 FCFA; this will allow her to pay her children's school fees. Her ambition is to diversify her business by selling flasks or gourds made from calabash.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a refrigerator

loans.name: God Bless Business Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “God Bless Business” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are small-scale salespeople. They have come to SMT, a partner of Shine on Sierra Leone, to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 for each borrower in order to expand the size and quality of their businesses. Consequently, they will be able to better support their children.

Salamatu K. (pictured on the left) is the leader of this group of borrowers. Salamatu was born in Lunsar, a small town in northern Sierra Leone. She is twenty-eight years of age, married to a businessman, and they have two children. Salamatu sells palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil), vegetable oil, ground-nut/peanuts, soaps, dishes, rubber bowls, etc. She has been a businesswoman for five years. With her share of this loan, she will buy the above mentioned items in wholesale to add to her current ones.

loans.use: To buy palm-oil, vegetable oil, ground-nut/peanuts, soaps, dishes, rubber bowls, etc.

loans.name: Hold Tight Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Hold Tight” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT, a Kiva field partner, to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 for each member of the group. With the help of this loan, they will be able to buy more goods, make more sales and, consequently, improve their living conditions. 

Thirty-year-old Nancy K. is the leader of this group. Nancy, who was born in Makeni, is married to a driver and they have two children. For more than twenty years, Nancy has been a businesswoman. She sells pepper. With the help of this loan, Nancy will be able to buy more pepper to add to her business inventory.

loans.use: To buy more pepper

loans.name: Wait For Me Group

texts.en:
Here are small-scale entrepreneurs from Makeni City, in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 500,000 for each person in the group to further strengthen their businesses. With the help of the loan, they will be able to buy more goods, attract more customers, make more sales and profit, and consequently improve their living conditions.

Isatu K., who is pictured second from left, is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. The forty-two-year-old is married to a driver and they have two children who attend primary schools. Isatu has been a businesswoman for two years. Isatu sells bowls, dishes, spoons, knives, palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil) and sugar. With her share of the loan, she will buy the above mentioned items in wholesale to add to her current ones.

loans.use: Buys bowls, dishes, spoons, knives, palm-oil and sugar

loans.name: Kamathor Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the “Kamathor” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. These women are small-scale local entrepreneurs who want to develop their businesses, but lack sufficient capital. Therefore, they formed a group to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 each from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they can attract more customers, make more sales and, consequently, improve their living conditions.

Their leader, Magret C., is pictured in the middle, receiving the loan from loan officer Zainab Bangura. The 45-year-old was born in Makeni, is married to an architect, and they have six children, one of whom still attends primary school. For twenty years, Magret has been selling rice, palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil) and firewood. With her share of the loan, she will buy bags of rice, gallons of palm-oil, and piles of firewood to add to her current ones.

loans.use: Buy bags of rice, gallons of palm-oil, and piles of firewood

loans.name: Kamara Group

texts.en:
Meet members of the K. Group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. These businesswomen have come together to form a group in order to request a loan of SLL 500,000 for each woman from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and, consequently, improve their living conditions.

This group’s leader is Isatu K., who is pictured on the left. The forty-seven-year-old was born in Kalamgba in northern Sierra Leone. She is a widow with five children, two of whom still attend secondary school. For two years, Isatu has been selling firewood. However, with this loan, she will invest it in palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil) and rice.

loans.use: Buy palm-oil and rice.

loans.name: Harvest Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the “Harvest” group from the small town of Waterloo. This where Shine on Sierra Leone partnered with SMT to start a branch. These small-businesspeople are seeking a loan of SLL 500,000 each to further strengthen their businesses.

The leader of this group is Alusine K., who is pictured on the left. Born in Waterloo, near Freetown, the twenty-seven-year-old is single and sells cigarettes, candles, milk, sardines, matches, batteries, soaps, etc. in a small shop. He has been running his business for two years. With his share of this loan, he will expand his business by buying the above-mentioned items in large quantities.

loans.use: Buy cigarettes, candles, milk, sardine, matches, batteries, soaps, etc.

loans.name: Serious Traders Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Serious Traders” from the small town of Waterloo. This is where “Shine on Sierra Leone” partnered with SMT to start a branch. These small-scale businesspeople have applied for a loan of SLL 500,000 each to further strengthen their businesses. 

The leader of this group is Chernor S., who is pictured on the left. Born in the Port Loko district, the approximately thirty-three-year-old is married to a businesswoman and they have three children who attend primary school. For fifteen years, Chernor has been selling soaps, toothpastes, toothbrushes, foot-brushes, torch lights, cosmetics, etc. With this loan, Chernor will buy the above mentioned items in wholesale to add to his business inventory.

loans.use: To buy soaps, tooth-pastes, tooth-brushes, foot-brushes, torch lights, cosmetics, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of peanut

loans.name: We Need Help Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “We Need Help” group from the small town of Waterloo. This is where “Shine on Sierra Leone” has partnered with SMT to start a branch. These small-scale businesswomen have applied for a loan of SLL 500,000 each from SMT/Kiva lenders to further strengthen their businesses. In this way, they can make more sales, better profit and, consequently, improve their living conditions.

Thirty-seven-year-old Marie F., pictured on the left, is the leader of this group of borrowers. Marie who was born in Waterloo, is married, and has two children, both of whom attend secondary school. For more than fifteen years, Marie has been a businesswoman. She sells items such as onions, vegetable oil, clothes, and any other goods she finds lucrative for the time. Marie also owns a bar where she sells both soft and hard drinks. She also sells cooked rice, meat, and vegetables. With her share of this loan, she will invest in her cooked-rice business by buying rice and palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil) in large quantities.

loans.use: Buy rice and palm-oil in large quantities

loans.name: Ibrahim P.'s Group

texts.en:
These are staff members of the RC Primary School, Binkolo. RC Primary School is located in Binkolo Village about six miles from Makeni City. The school was built by Plan International, a non-governmental organization, in 1980, but it is now run by the Catholic Mission in Binkolo Village. The school has a total of fourteen dedicated staff on their payroll and 476 pupils. 

This is the second loan these teachers are requesting from SMT/Kiva Lenders. School staff from this institution, like many other schools staff within SMT’s operational areas, comes to SMT to apply for loans. With the help of these loans, they can accomplish some certain tasks that they would otherwise have not being able to accomplish with their mere salaries alone. But with the help of this loan, some can pay school fees for their children, others can use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, a plot of land, house-building materials, or invest in a business. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan from their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT on their behalf.

Ibrahim P. K. (first row, left) is the leader of this group of teachers. The forty-six-year-old Ibrahim was born in Binkolo Village, is married to a businesswoman, and they have three children. Ibrahim has been teaching for sixteen years. He is requesting a loan of SLL 900,000 to buy house-building materials, like cement and iron-corrugated zincs. 

(Attached to this photo is a snapshot of a borrower who was not able to be present for the group photo).

loans.use: To buy house-building materials, such as cement and iron-corrugated zinc

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Madame Fatoumata S. est âgée de 42 ans, mariée  mère de  4 enfants.  Elle  vit  dans une famille nucléaire avec son mari et ses enfants au quartier Bagadadji de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
 Matrone de profession, elle commença à faire le commerce quand elle servait dans une commune. Les femmes de cette commune voulant organiser une grande cérémonie festive, on sollicite son concours. Depuis lors elle est dans cette activité de commerce qu’elle mène il y’a maintenant 10 ans et  jouit d’une grande clientèle et notoriété. Sa force de vente est due à la qualité de ses habits. 
Dans le dessein de  faire face une commande venant du Niger où ses habits sont beaucoup appréciés, elle a  fait recours à   Soro Yiriwaso. 
Après 6 prêts solidaires et 2 prêts  individuels tous  bien remboursés,  elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel qu’elle compte utiliser  pour acheter, 15 pièces de pagnes wax. Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako et vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée exclusivement de femmes. 
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel 140 000 FCFA, ce dernier lui permettra de payer des moquettes et un congélateur pour sa fille qui va se marier. 
Son ambition est  de construire une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatoumata S. is 42 years old, married and mother to four children. She lives in a nuclear family with her husband and children in the Bagadadji district of the town of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). A matron by profession, she began trading when she was working in a municipality. When the women from this municipality wanted to organise a large festive ceremony, they sought her help. Since then and for the past ten years she has been carrying out her business and she now enjoys a large customer base and a good reputation. The strength of her sales is due to the quality of her clothes. With the aim of coping with an order from Niger, where her clothes are much appreciated, she has turned to Soro Yiriwaso. Having already had six group loans and two individual loans, all of which were repaid on time, she is now on her third individual loan. She is planning to use this to buy 15 pieces of "pagnes wax" (West African highly decorative and colourful fabric). She gets her supplies in Bamako and sells for cash and on credit to a customer base made up exclusively of women. She envisages making a monthly profit of 140,000 FCFA which will allow her to pay for carpets and a freezer for her daughter who is getting married. Her ambition is to buy a house to live in.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothes

loans.name: Sa

texts.en:
Sa N., 50, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Battambong Province, Cambodia, an area known for its good quality rice products. 

She sells groceries at home for a gross income of about USD 20 per day. Her husband is a skillful fisherman, earning an income of USD 5 per day to help cover the family's expenses.  

Sa N. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase more groceries to stock the store. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to expand her current business.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Anh's Group

texts.en:
Anh T. V. N. was born in 1984. She lives in Kinh No village with her husband and her two children. She has a store. She has a monthly income of about 4,000,000 Vietnam dong (VND). 

Ms. Anh has participated in SEDA's microfinancing program since 2005. She borrowed 5,014,000 VND for her last loan and has completely repaid this amount. In this loan cycle, Ms. Anh would like to borrow 7,630,000 VND to invest in her store. 

She is the group leader of a eight–member group. About members in her group:

 Hoach T. N. is 57 years old. She wants to borrow 7,194,000 VND to invest in her store.
 Mui T. N. is 46 years old. She wants to borrow 5,450,000 VND to breed pigs and poultry.
 Hoa T. N. is 40 years old. She wants to borrow 6,322,000 VND to buy food for fish.
 Cuc T. N. is 60 years old. She has a store, and she wants to borrow 6,322,000 VND to invest in her store.
 Dien T. T. is 37 years old. She wants to borrow 6,322,000 VND for her small business.
 Lien T. N. is 28 years old. She wants to borrow 5,450,000 VND to breed chickens.
 Thuy T. T. is 35 years old. She wants to borrow 5,450,000 VND to expand her business.

loans.use: To invest in her store

loans.name: Honest, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
In business, first impressions mean everything. That is one adage that never slips N. Florence’s mind. In her three years doing business, her commitment, friendly nature, and hard work have brought her dividends in her tailoring business in Ibanda town.

This is the fascinating story of a young single go-getter business lady. Her business, since its inception, has steadily been bringing her profits to the tune of 70,000 shillings weekly. With this loan she is gleefully upbeat that her business will gain further ground as she intends to buy more sewing machines.

loans.use: To purchase more sewing machines in attempt to expand business

loans.name: Sujeewa

texts.en:
Sujeewa is a 37-year-old married woman living with her husband in the town of Telijjawila in southern Sri Lanka. She has two daughters and her husband works as a mason.    

Sujeewa has managed a vegetable cultivation business for a long time and she is very enthusiastic about her business.

Sujeewa has requested a 20,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to help her cultivation. She is grateful to BRAC Sri Lanka because of the financial support it provides to her.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy materials and equipment for the vegetable cultivation business

loans.name: Lun

texts.en:
Lun L., 60, is married and resides with his wife and four children in Battambong Province, Cambodia, an area known for its good quality rice products. He is a farmer who grows vegetables and rice for an income of about USD 3 per day. His wife is a farmer, too, earning an income of USD 3 per day to help cover the family's expenses.  

L. is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase a motorbike to transport his agricultural products to sell at the market. In the future, he would like to use any additional profit to expand his current business.  This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Phen

texts.en:
Phen P., 60, is married and resides with his wife and four children in Battambong Province, Cambodia, an area known for its good quality rice products. He and his wife are butchers and sell pork for a gross income of about USD 50 per day.  

P. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase pigs to slaughter for pork to sell. In the future, he would like to use any additional profit to expand his current business.  This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. P.'s wife is pictured here.

loans.use: To more pigs to slaughter for pork to sell

loans.name: Wali Mohammad

texts.en:
Wali M. is the son of S. M.. He lives in Bagrami, Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married and lives in a household with five members. 

He has a general store where he is very busy working in order to earn money and meet the daily requirements of his family members. He needs the Kiva loan to purchase sanitary products, beverages and the other requirements of his business. 

He is glad that, through this process, he can develop his business.

loans.use: To grow his business

loans.name: Bun

texts.en:
Bun P., 40, is married and resides with his wife and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. He is a motor-taxi driver in the city and earns an income of about USD 3.60 per day. His wife is a farmer, earning an income of USD 0.50 per day to help cover the family's expenses.  

P. is requesting a loan of USD 1,100 to purchase blacksmith equipment to expand his child’s business. In the future, he would like to use any additional profit to repair his house.  This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy blacksmith equipment

loans.name: Sophie

texts.fr: Sophie S. Est âgée de 41 ans, elle est mariée sans enfants mais tutrice de 6 enfants qui lui sont confiés par des parents et/ou proches. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de DIAMAKHEUL depuis 7 ans et a 14 fois de suite bénéficié de crédit et n'a jamais eu de problème. Elle fait de l'embouche ovine et son prêt lui permettra de mieux développer son activité par l'achat de 15 moutons, de les engraisser et revendre au bout de 4 à 5 mois au niveau des marchés hebdomadaires de sa localité. Elle participe à l'amélioration de conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Sophie S. is 41 years old. She is married and has no children of her own, but she is the guardian of six children who have been entrusted to her care by relatives and/or close friends. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois in DIAMAKHEUL for seven years and has had 14 consecutive loans; she has never had any problem repaying these. She has a sheep fattening activity, and her loan will allow her to develop her business by purchasing 15 sheep, fattening them up and selling them after four to five months at weekly markets in her town. She is contributing to the improvement of her family's living conditions.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her self-financing capacity

loans.name: Fama

texts.fr: Fama G. est une femme de 63 ans, elle mariée et  mère de 6 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de DIAMAKHEUL depuis 7 ans et demi et y a reçu 15 fois de suite de crédit qu'elle a toujours remboursés sans difficulté. Son activité principale est la vente de petits ruminants, mais parallèlement elle vend des produits divers tels que des denrées alimentaires et effets vestimentaires. Elle participe à  l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Fama G. is a 63-year old woman who is married and mother to six children. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois in DIAMAKHEUL for seven and a half years and has had 15 consecutive loans, which she has always repaid without difficulty. Her primary activity is the sale of small ruminants but, at the same time, she sells various products, such as food and clothing. She is contributing to the improvement in her family's living conditions.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Strengthen and promote her businesses

loans.name: Mestari Group

texts.en:
Zabiullah is the group leader of Mestari group.  He lives in district 8 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married and lives in a household with five members. He is a responsible man and works hard for his family to have comfortable life. 

He has a workshop where he repairs different kinds of cars. He needs the loan to purchase car parts and essential tools for repairing cars. 

He is confident that he will make his payments on time to repay the loan and will apply for another loan as soon as he finishes his repayment.

loans.use: To purchase car parts and tools to expand his business

loans.name: Geethani

texts.en:
Geethani is a hard working 44-year-old married woman living with her husband, two daughters, and one son in the town of Telijjawila in southern Sri Lanka.

Geethani is managing a business where she makes spices. She has been doing this for eight months.  In her business, she buys spices, then grinds and packages them to sell to shops. 

She has asked for a loan of 20,000 LKR from BRAC to help purchase a grinding mill.

Thank you for considering supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To purchase a grinding mill

loans.name: Bakyala Kwekulakulana Group 2, Lugazi

texts.en:
At the start of N. Sauda’s produce and wholesale business in 2003, somebody laid a bet that her business would not see the light of day after a month’s course. The skepticism was a no-brainer to her, as she had set out her objectives to succeed by then. She had to bring her guts and determination to bear in the face of such low expectations from some of her disparaging friends.

With huge reserves of optimism and with a desire to prove her detractors wrong, 35-year-old Sauda embarked on her mission – to get established in the business genre of her preference, to wit: a produce sales and small commodity wholesale business. She went out of her depth to fight off the early financial quagmires that had reared their heads and were making her chances of success hang in the balance.

Sauda started getting into her stride when she began selling rice, groundnuts (peanuts), beans and millet. When her prospects began improving, her down-the-line attitude got even better. As a consequence, all her three children, who were hitherto not going to school, began attending school.

Sauda’s customers are mostly small retailers. In a month, she says she earns to the tune of 600,000 shillings. She is also a counselor within her locality. With this loan she wants to buy some produce she has not sold before like coffee and cotton. She also wants to buy more matches, textbooks and tea leaves for her wholesale stock.

loans.use: To purchase crops such as coffee that she has not sold before and also some wholesale stock

loans.name: Jappo Liggey (Asf) N°11 Group

texts.fr:
Jappo Ligguey (asf)  est une association mixte composée de plusieurs personnes microentrepreuneuses. Elle a été créée en 2009 par un groupe de femmes pour  rassembler  tous leurs  paires  du  quartier  Angle Serigne Fallou  (asf) autour d’un même idéal  « l’entraide  pour travailler ». Elle est dirigée par Madame Marie N. Diouf et  est scindée en plusieurs sous groupes de 5 sous l’influence de l’agent de crédit de la caisse Moda Kane pour  que tous  les membres  puissent  bénéficier mieux des services d’U-IMCEC. C’est ainsi que certains sous groupes ont déposé leur demande de crédit de 500 000 FCFA qu’ils vont se partager en part égale.
Jappo Liggey N°11 est géré par Madame Penda C. commerçante de petits déjeuners devant le CEM du quartier depuis 2002. Elle s’active également dans la vente de bijoux, miel et huile de palme. Par rapport au choix de ce business, Madame Penda C. dit : «  je n’avais pas reçu de formation durant toute ma vie et lorsque j’ai voulu combattre l’oisiveté le commerce était le secteur que je pouvais embrasser car j’étais très ouverte et je me disais très souvent que le commerce n’est rien que le tissage de relation, ce qui était facile à mon endroit ». Cependant, avec sa part du prêt Madame C. voudrait compléter son budget d’approvisionnement.
Madame Aïda T. est la trésorière. Elle est vendeuse de petit déjeuner et de diner à Grand Thiès  depuis 6 ans. Les autres membres sont Monsieur Thierno N. vendeur ambulant d’oignons, habits, chaussettes et chaussures à travers les marchés de Thiès, Madame Khady Diagne M. vendeuse de friperie et de diner à Randoulène Nord un quartier populaire de Thiès et Madame Aïssata D. qui vend des bols, assiettes, tissus et de l’encens.
texts.en:
Jappo Ligguey (ASF) is a mixed association composed of multiple individuals running small enterprises. It has been created in 2009 by a group of women who wanted to bring together all their peers in the district of Angle Serigne Fallou (ASF) under the slogan “mutual aid for doing work.” The group is lead by Mrs. Marie N. Diouf and is organized into multiple sub-groups of five, as advised by the agent of the Moda Kane credit union, so that all members could better benefit from U-IMCEC services. Thus several sub-groups have requested a loan of 500,000 West African francs, which will be divided equally among the members. Jappo Liggey # 11 is managed by Mrs. Penda C., who has been selling breakfast foods in front of the local school since 2002. She also sells jewelry, honey and palm oil. As regards her choice of trade, Mrs. Penda Cisokho says the following: “I never had schooling in all my life, and when I wanted to find a useful occupation, commerce was something I could deal with as I kept an open mind and told myself that very often commerce is simply about networking, which was easy to do in the place where I live.” And so with her part of the loan Mrs. C. would like to boost her budget for restocking. Mrs. Aida T. is the treasurer. She has been selling breakfast and dinner foods in Grand Thiès for six years. The other members are Mr. Thierno Nidaye, a street vendor selling onions, clothing, socks and shoes at different markets in Thiès, Mrs. Khady Diagne M., who sells second-hand clothes and dinner foods in Randoulène Nord, a modest district of Thiès, and Mrs. Aissanta D., who sells bowls, plates, fabrics and incense.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Replenishing merchandise stock

loans.name: Family Tree Group

texts.en:
George K. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called Family Tree. He is 30 years old and single without a child, though he cares for two siblings. He could not continue his education through the 12th grade.

For three years, George has been a commercial motor bike driver around downtown Monrovia, Liberia. He started his business by selling shoes.

George cleans his bike well and also keeps himself neat in order attract customers. His goal is to expand his business and save more money for investment.

George plans to use his portion of 6,000 Liberian dollars from the group loan amount of 30,000 Liberian dollars to improve the status of his present motor bike.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, George is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution, with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.


Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today: http://www.kiva.org/team/team_leap_liberia

loans.use: To improve his motor bike.

loans.name: Leema Group

texts.en:
Mahtab Gul is a member of Leema group. She lives in district 8 of Kabul, Afghanistan. 

She is married with four children. They are students at school. She is a tailor and has been involved in this business for more than eight years. She is quite experienced in her business and has lots of clients as well.

She needs the loan to buy a new machine because her old one was damaged and it doesn’t work well after the repairs.

She would like to thank Kiva lenders a lot.

loans.use: To buy a new machine for her business

loans.name: Jappo Liggey (Asf) N°8 Group

texts.fr:
Jappo Ligguey (asf)  est une association mixte composée de plusieurs personnes microentrepreuneuses. Elle a été créée en 2009 par un groupe de femmes pour  rassembler  tous leurs  paires  du  quartier  Angle Serigne Fallou  (asf) autour d’un même idéal  « l’entraide  pour travailler ». Elle est dirigée par Madame Marie N. Diouf et  est scindée en plusieurs sous groupes de 5 sous l’influence de l’agent de crédit de la caisse Moda Kane pour  que tous  les membres  puissent  bénéficier mieux des services d’U-IMCEC. C’est ainsi que certains sous groupes ont déposé leur demande de crédit de 500 000 FCFA qu’ils vont se partager en part égale. 
Le sous groupe Jappo Liggey N°8 est dirigé par Madame Khady S. âgée de 59 ans. Cette dame fait le commerce d’arachide, niébé ou haricot local, mil, chez elle depuis 8 ans. Elle dirige dans ce sous groupe Madame Sokhna N. Gaye qui vend du thiouraye (encens), crème et du  jus de fruit, Madame Ndéye S. vendeuse de petit déjeuners et oignon, Monsieur Papa Modou M. qui s’active dans la  vente de friperie au marché centrale de Thiès et de Madame Adama Guèye également dans la friperie au niveau des marchés hebdomadaires. e idéal  « l’entraide  pour travailler ». Elle est dirigée par Madame Marie N. Diouf et  est scindée en plusieurs sous groupes de 5 sous l’influence de l’agent de crédit de la caisse Moda Kane pour  que tous  les membres  puissent  bénéficier mieux des services d’U-IMCEC. C’est ainsi que certains sous groupes ont déposé leur demande de crédit de 500 000 FCFA qu’ils vont se partager en part égale.
texts.en:
Jappo Ligguey (ASF) is a mixed association composed of multiple individuals running small enterprises. It has been created in 2009 by a group of women who wanted to bring together all their peers in the district of Angle Serigne Fallou (ASF) under the slogan “mutual aid for doing work.” The group is led by Mrs. Marie N. Diouf and is organized into multiple sub-groups of five, as advised by the agent of the Moda Kane credit union, so that all members can better benefit from U-IMCEC services. Thus several sub-groups have requested a loan of 500,000 West African francs, which will be divided equally among the members. The Jappo Liggey subgroup No. 8 is managed by Mrs. Khady S., 59 years of age. She has been selling peanuts, “ niébé" [a local type of black-eyed beans] and millet from her home for the past eight years. The other members of the subgroup she manages are Mrs. Sokhna N. Gaye, who sells “thiouraye” incense [a traditional mixture of grains and fragrant wood that is burnt with coal or charcoal]. ice cream and fruit juices; Mrs. Ndéye S., who sells breakfast foods and onions; Mr. Papa Moudou M., who sells second-hand clothing at the central market of Thiès; and Mrs. Adama Guèye, who also sells second-hand clothing at the weekly markets.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing stock items for their respective lines of commerce

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en: Hawa I. sells provisions at Abura. Hawa has received a senior high education. She is divorced and stays with her three children. Her loan will be used to buy extra provisions to fill her shop. She is responsible for paying utility bills and accommodations. She hopes to use the new earnings from her business to save to complete her house.

loans.use: To buy extra provisions to fill her shop.

loans.name: Jappo Liggey (Asf) N°10 Group

texts.fr:
Jappo Ligguey (asf)  est une association mixte composée de plusieurs personnes microentrepreuneuses. Elle a été créée en 2009 par un groupe de femmes pour  rassembler  tous leurs  paires  du  quartier  Angle Serigne Fallou  (asf) autour d’un même idéal  « l’entraide  pour travailler ». Elle est dirigée par Madame Marie N. D. et  est scindée en plusieurs sous groupes de 5 sous l’influence de l’agent de crédit de la caisse Moda Kane pour  que tous  les membres  puissent  bénéficier mieux des services d’U-IMCEC. C’est ainsi que certains sous groupes ont déposé leur demande de crédit de 500 000 FCFA qu’ils vont se partager en part égale. 
Pour le sous groupe Jappo Liggey N°10, Madame Ndéye D. est la présidente. Elle est commerçante de fruits et chaussures depuis 30 ans en face de la gare routière pour se profiter de la plupart des clients qui emprunte très souvent le train pour le transport. Comme  les autres membres du sous groupe, Madame Ndéye D. souhaitait renouveler leur stock de marchandises avec le prêt octroyé.  Elle partage ce sous groupe avec Madame Astou N. qui vend des habits pour femme, Madame Amsatou N. commerçante de tissus, pagnes, ferr (perles) et colliers au niveau du marché Moussanté de Thiès, Madame Khady D. vendeuse de petits déjeuners et diner chez elle et de Madame Ndéye M. la trésorière qui vend des pagnes tissées, du petit déjeuner et diner dans sa kiosque qu’elle a installée à coté de chez elle.
texts.en:
Jappo Ligguey (asf) is a mixed association composed of several micro-entrepreneurial people.  It was created in 2009 by a group of women for gathering all their peers in the Angle Serigne Fallou (asf) district to focus on the same ideal:  mutual aid for work.  It is lead by Ms. Marie N. D. and is divided into several sub-groups of five. It is guided by the loan agent of the Moda Kane branch office, so that all the members may benefit more from U-IMCEC services.  And so, certain sub-groups have applied for a loan of 500,000 francs CFA that they will share equally with each other.  In sub-group Jappo Liggey N°10, Ms. Ndéye D. is the president.  She has been a merchant of fruit and vegetables for thirty years and is located opposite the bus station in order to take advantage of the bulk of customers who very often take the train.  Like the other members of the sub-group, Ms. Ndéye D. would want to replenish their stock of merchandise with the loan granted.  She shares in this sub-group with Ms. Astou N., who sells women's clothing;  Ms. Amsatou N., a merchant of fabrics, pagne cloth, ferr (pearls), and necklaces at the Moussanté market of Thiès;  Ms. Khady D., a breakfast and lunch vendor at her home; and Ms. Ndéye M., the treasurer, who sells woven pagne cloth and breakfast and dinner in a stall, which she set up next to her home.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Replenishing their inventories

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan is a 35-year-old married man with four children. They live in southern Lebanon in a town named Bint Jbeil. Hassan has been working in the construction business for the past 14 years, since he was very young. He is a freelance worker who specializes in concrete for construction. He has built up a good business reputation.

Therefore, for the second time, Hassan is asking for a loan to purchase tools and materiA. for concrete. These new tools will allow him to improve his work. He's confident that the loan will allow him to increase his business productivity because when he first started his business he had some financiA. issues.

loans.use: To purchase tools and material for concrete

loans.name: Champika

texts.en:
Champika is a 26-year-old married woman living with her husband and son in the town of Telijjawila in the Matara area of Sri Lanka.  She is a hard working woman.  Her husband cultivates crops and Champika provides support to her husband in this business. They are very close and work well together.  

Additionally, Champika sells clothes as a second business, something she has been doing for a long time. She manages this business alongside helping with the crop cultivation.

Champika has requested a 60,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to help her and her husband's crop cultivation business.  They plan to use the loan to help purchase agricultural equipment. She is grateful to BRAC Sri Lanka because of the financial support it provides to her.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy crop cultivation equipment

loans.name: Jamal

texts.en: Jamal is a 40-year-old man who owns a bakery in his hometown of Bint Jbeil in southern Lebanon. A father of three, he opened his bakery in order to improve his family’s income and to be able to provide the best for his family. Jamal bakes mankoucheh, a traditional type of Lebanese bread which is usually topped with zaater -- a thyme-like herb -- and cheese or minced meat. It can be found in the hands of nearly every Lebanese person for either breakfast or lunch. The tasty bread is almost always served warm, and Jamal supplies locals with soft, fresh mankoucheh every day. Jamal has asked Al Majmoua, a Kiva partner, for a loan in order to purchase raw materials and soft drinks to sell to his clients. He is grateful for the opportunity provided to him, and he is confident that this loan will enable him to sustain his business and continue to support his family.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials and soft drinks

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en:
Adjoa A. processes palm oil for sale at Abura.  Adjoa has been through junior high school. She is married to a carpenter and lives with her four children. Adjoa has been selling palm oil for about three years now. She helps her husband with the general upkeep of the home. Her loan will be added to her initial income to buy a palm oil extractor to be able to extract more oil to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest back into her business.

To prepare her locally made palm oil, she gets her palm nuts from the farmers on the farm. She washes them and boils them for about 40 minutes until they become soft and tender. The cooked fruits are strained, put into a big mortar and gently squeezed with a pestle, avoiding damaging the nut but only to peel the pulp covering the nut. Water is then added to it. The juice obtained is strained, separating the nut and taking out the chaff with the hand. (The chaff is sometimes used by the local people to light charcoal fire). The juice is boiled again and as it boils, the fresh oil will be seen floating whilst the water keeps boiling beneath. The scooped oil is left to cool and later bottled or preserved for sale. Fresh oil from palm fruits are traditionally used in eating roasted yam or plantain in Africa, especially on the farms after a hard days work.

loans.use: To buy a palm oil extractor to be able to extract more oil to sell.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 28-year-old single man living with his family in Bint Jbeil, southern Lebanon. He has been working as a car mechanic in his village since 2008, having learned this occupation from his previous work. 

Since he opened his garage, Ahmad’s business operation has grown. Thus, he wants to take a loan to buy additional new and sophisticated tools for his garage. These will allow him to improve his work efficiency. With his business income, he provides, along with his father and brothers, for the living expenses of the family.

loans.use: To buy tools.

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan is a 29-year-old man who lives in Bint Jbeil, southern Lebanon with his wife and their two children. Hassan has been working in agriculture since 2005. He owns livestock and also plants some fruits and vegetables. 

He requested a loan from Kiva's partner Al Majmoua in order to purchase a cow to increase his livestock. This is the first time he has requested a loan. Hassan is special in his work because he does his best to produce the best quality. His clients are people from his region. When he first started his business, he didn’t use to produce as much as he does today. Hassan decided on doing his business because of his experience. In the future, he plans to keep on expanding his work by producing more.

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Amal

texts.en:
Amal is a 33-year-old married woman living in Bint Jbeil, southern Lebanon. She owns a hairdressing salon. Amal hopes for a loan to buy more tools and beauty products. She also plans on opening a snack stand in order to improve her family’s income. 

Amal is an active woman who does her best to improve her financial condition. She decided on doing her work because of her experience. This is the first time she has requested a loan.

loans.use: To buy more tools and beauty products

loans.name: Bassem

texts.en:
Bassem is a 42-year-old man who resides in Bint Jbeil, southern Lebanon, with his wife and their child. Bassem has a fruit and vegetable shop. He has been in this business for 10 years and has been able to attract many customers who buy fruits or vegetables in his neighborhood since he sells good quality products. 

He is requesting a loan for the second time from Al Majmoua, a Kiva partner, so that he can buy fruits and vegetables. This will help him become more competitive in the market. His previous loan allowed him to purchase merchandise and provide the best to his clients. For the future, he plans to keep on improving his work by purchasing and offering the best produce and also purchasing more exotic fruits and vegetables depending on the season.

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy fuel to transport charcoal from the production site to her business center

loans.name: Bright Future Employees, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
There is a fascinating story behind hardworking K. Moses. This hardworking married father of two children began his retail shop dealing in general merchandise two years ago in Kihihi town.

Through acquiring loans from this micro-finance institute, he was able to start up his side business to help him generate more income for his family alongside his teaching profession. With this loan he will be able to purchase more goods and be able to improve his earnings as he looks forward to living a self-sustaining life.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for his store

loans.name: Najeeba Nanwa Group

texts.en:
Najeeba is the leader of Najeeba Nanwa group. She lives in the 8th district of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married with five children. They are students in school. She has a bakery in her house and she is quite famous among her neighbors as they really like the bread she bakes. Most of her clients are her neighbors. 

She wants to take the loan to purchase firewood and flour. Also, she needs to paint her room and make it organized to attract more clients. She hopes to expand her business and to open a shop instead of working in her house.

loans.use: Purchase firewood and flour

loans.name: Khoder

texts.en:
Khoder is a 33-year-old married man and father of two children. He has been working as a home and furniture painter. He works on a freelance basis, upon the request of clients. He works hard to satisfy the demands of his job in order to pay his daily expenses and provide a better life for his family. 

His previous loan allowed him to purchase new and better tools to improve his work. He is requesting a second loan to purchase paint tools and a car for his business so that he can carry his tools and go from one client to another. For the future, he plans to keep on improving his work, as well as his financial situation.

loans.use: To purchase paint tools and a car for his business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary A. is married to a farmer and lives with her six dependants. She has received a junior high education.  Mary sells second hand clothes at Abura. Mary uses the income she generates from her sales to help her husband in the payment of school fees, utility bills and other family expenses.  Mary will use the loan to purchase additional second hand clothes to sell. With the new profits from her extended business, Mary plans to save to buy a shop.

loans.use: To purchase additional second hand clothes to sell

loans.name: Nanso Development Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
Shalo S. is a focused 32-year-old happily married man. He has six children, with only four going to school on the grounds of his modest earnings.

S. has subsisted on a low-earning fishing and retailing business for the last two years in his area of Nanso, Buziika, and Lugazi. He mostly sells fish, sugar, salt, paraffin, soap and oil. In a month he excitedly says he makes more than 300,000 shillings and is looking forward to making even more with the acquisition of this loan. Behind the excitement however, he knows he has responsibility that he owes to his children, especially those not at school.

With no previous business experience, S., to all intents and purposes, got started in his business on a low-key note with persuasion from his brother who was also inclined towards doing business. From then on he did not rest on his laurels as he knew he had to work hard to see success within his grasp. With this determination, his business turned a new leaf. The benefactors are his first two children: he managed to provide for their education.

With this loan, S. is optimistic that his businesses will see a new lease of life as he intends to buy fishing nets and additional retail stock. He also wants to fully educate all his children.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets and additional retail stock

loans.name: Mohammad Ali

texts.en: Mohammad Ali is a 22-year-old engaged man who is living with his family until he gets married. He lives in Bin Jbeil, southern Lebanon. During the day, he operates a butcher shop. He has been operating his meat trading business since 2006 and has steadily expanded his business. At the beginning, his working capital was low which didn’t allow him to purchase a lot of meat to sell, but through his hard work and determination, as well as his previous two loans, he was able to diversify his merchandise. Today he requested a loan in order to purchase meat for his shop, as well as furnish his new home so that by the time he gets married, all is ready. Mohammad Ali has great communication skills and is a very hard working person.

loans.use: To buy more meat to sell.

loans.name: Nataliya

texts.en:
Nataliya is married with two children. She sells children's clothing and toys at one of the markets in Zaporozhye city. Nataliya enjoys her business. Seeing happy children when their parents buy them toys makes Nataliya happy as well.

Nataliya has been in this business for 10 years. She is a very open, sincere and responsible person. She says that business loans help her to purchase inventory in bulk and increase the assortment. This brings more customers to her kiosk and increases the sales. This time Nataliya would like to borrow 12,100 UAH to purchase more summer inventories.

loans.use: To purchase inventories

loans.name: Ludmila

texts.en: Ludmila is married with one child. She sells clothing at an open market in Nova Kahovka town. Ludmila has been in this business for seven years. She enjoys selling men's clothing and has many repeat clients. Ludmila would like to borrow 14,350 UAH to purchase more inventories. She hopes to receive additional income and spend it to improve her family living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase more inventories

loans.name: Taatai Ole

texts.en:
Taatai ole N. is 29 years old and married to Jackline N.. Together they have one school-going child. 

Taatai is a farmer and he does wheat farming; this he has done for the last four years.

He learned about KADET from a colleague who is already a Kadet registered client. This will be his second loan. He is planning to plant 20 acres of wheat. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to hire more land for farming to increase his wheat production and buy some sheep for fattening to sell later.

His dream is that he will be able to buy a bigger piece of land whereby he can plant more wheat for commercial purposes and keep more sheep.

loans.use: To plant more wheat and buy sheep.

loans.name: Koitat

texts.en:
Koitat N. is 39 years old and married to Kibiyoto N.. He is a father of three children, all of whom are currently attending school. Koitat is a farmer and he has been in the farming business for the last six years.

He learned about Kiva Field Partner 'KADET' from other members in his home area who had already registered as KADET clients. Koitat is now on his second loan cycle with the organization and with this loan he plans to plant twenty acres of wheat, which has been doing very well in his area. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to lease more land for farming to increase his wheat production. The area has favorable climate conditions for wheat farming, thus making him think of these operations as a sole specialty.

His future dream is to buy a bigger piece of land whereby he can expand his wheat farming for commercial purposes and be the leading farmer in his area.

loans.use: To prepare land for wheat planting.

loans.name: Progress Family Group

texts.en:
Thomas T. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called Progress Family. He is 45 years old, married, and has seven children who range from 18 to 28 years old. He was not privileged to attend school. For 7 years, Thomas has been selling hardware like cutlasses, door locks, and keys at the Via Town market in Monrovia. He sells in a friendly manner, which keeps customers returning. He started his business with 1,000 Liberian dollars. Thomas plans to use his 4,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 22,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more cutlasses, nails, locks, and keys. His goal is to grow his business and to continue to support his children so that they can have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Thomas is the one holding the sign.

loans.use: To buy more cutlasses, nails, locks, and keys

loans.name: Aba

texts.en:
Aba Y. is married and has seven dependents. She has been through senior high school.  Aba sells plastic bowls, moving from one house to the other in and around Abura, which she has been doing for some time now. Her husband is a farmer. 

Aba uses her income to help her husband in providing food, clothing and shelter for her family.  Aba will use the loan to purchase more and a greater variety of plastic bowls and foodstuffs like plantains which will serve as an additional trade to enter into and sell in her locality. With the new profits from her expanded business, Aba plans to reinvest back into her business.

loans.use: purchase more and a greater variety of plastic bowls etc. for resale

loans.name: Rosaline

texts.en:
Rosaline K. is married to John Mutai, and they have been blessed with four children, Emmanuel Tabut, Christine Jeptoo, Miriam Jerotich, and Esther Chebichi. They both practice agriculture on their farm and mainly specialize in maize cultivation. She sells her farm produce in small quantities to local customers within her area of residence. She has been doing this for six years.

Rosaline was introduced to KADET by her friend who was already an existing member. She has applied for a loan which she will use to prepare her one acre of land and buy phosphate fertilizers so that she can plant maize and use part of the money to open a retail shop.

She hopes that with the proceeds from the shop she will be able to pay school fees for her children when they join secondary school.

loans.use: To cultivate one acre of maize on her farm (at 6,000 KES) and use the remainder to open a retail shop (kiosk)

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella N. is a 32-year-old married mother of two children. She is married to John Kitsao, and the family lives in Mombasa's Mshomoroni estate.

Stella runs a retail shop in Mshomoroni, in an area called Stage ya Samaki, and her business has been in operation for eight years. Mshomoroni is densely populated, and retail kiosks are plentiful. The competition prompted Stella to seek an alternative income generator, and now she also owns an M-PESA service outlet in the same area.

Stella was introduced to KADET by an existing member and is now borrowing her first loan. She plans to restock her retail shop with maize flour, sugar, and rice in order to satisfy her clients, who are mainly area residents.

With subsequent loans from KADET, Stella hopes to upgrade to wholesale trading.

loans.use: To purchase flour, sugar, and rice for her retail kiosk. Also, to renew her business licence.

loans.name: Koipaso Enole

texts.en:
Koipaso Enole K. is 41 years old. She is married to Mainka K., and together they have seven children.

Koipaso is a farmer, and she does her farming on her own piece of land, something she has been doing for the last three years.

She learned about KADET from other women who were already registered members. This will be her first loan, and she is planning to use it to plant more wheat, which normally does well in her area due to good climatic conditions. She hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand her farming activity from small-scale to commercial farming.

Koipaso's dream is to do large-scale farming and attain financial independence. She is a hardworking woman who is determined to achieve her set goals.

loans.use: To plant more wheat on her farm

loans.name: Julius Tiampati

texts.en:
Julius Tiampati N. is 35 years old. He is married to Yiamat N., and he is a father of two school-going children.

Julius is a wheat farmer, and he has been farming for the last ten years.

He learned about KADET through a marketing campaign done by KADET staff in his area of residence. This will be his second loan, and he is planning to use it to plant twenty acres of wheat, which has proved to do very well in this area. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to lease more land for farming, to increase his wheat production, and buy some sheep to fatten and sell later.

His future dream is that he will become a large-scale farmer, both in wheat farming and sheep rearing.

loans.use: To prepare the land for wheat planting and buy sheep for fattening

loans.name: Kanungu Development Club Group

texts.en:
She has a big dream of owning a big farm in her home area of Kihihi. On the face of it now, N. Agnes is in far cry narrow circumstances that may make her seem like a wishful thinker. This means she faces long odds in achieving her dream. She however has, at length, built a strong attribute of determination that has played into her hands.

With strong customer care skills up her sleeve, Agnes has gotten for her garments-selling business a dependable niche. It is one she has banked on for the last three years. Her family of three children has also enjoyed the good graces that have come with her doing this business.

Monthly profits to the tune of 300,000 are what Agnes has been getting since she began. With this loan she hopes to purchase more clothes and also expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for her business

loans.name: Awa

texts.fr: Madame Awa D. est une femme mariée de 36 ans qui habite dans la localité de Bambilor depuis très  longtemps. Elle est membre de la caisse depuis décembre 2009 et elle  a déjà bénéficié d’un prêt antérieur.  Elle est marie et mère  de 6 enfants dont l’âge varie entre 1 et 13 ans.  C’est une commerçante qui évolue  dans l’achat et la vente d’œufs frais depuis 5 ans.  C’est après  son mariage qu’elle s’est lance  dans cette activité  dans le but de soutenir son mari a gérer les charges familiales. Ainsi avec ses bénéfices  elle parvient a assurer quelques dépenses  liées  aux besoins des enfants. Elle sollicite un crédit de 100 000 frs prévu  pour l’achat de 50 plateaux d’œufs destines a la vente. Pour Madame D. ce crédit lui permettra d’accroitre  ses revenus et de supporter d’autres charges lies aux besoins des enfants tels que gouter, argent de poche et de temps en temps l’achat de vêtements.
texts.en:
Mrs. Awa D. is a 36-year-old woman, who has lived in Bambilor for a long time. She has been a member of the local branch of U-IMCEC since December 2009, and has already been granted one previous loan. She is married and the mother of six children whose ages vary from 1 to 13 years. She has been actively involved in the commerce of fresh eggs for the past five years. She began this activity after her marriage, to assist her husband in dealing with family expenses. Indeed, her earnings enabled her to cover some expenses linked to the children’s needs. She is requesting a loan for 100,000 francs with which she will purchase 50 trays of eggs for sale. This loan will enable Mrs. D. to increase her income and take care of more of her children’s needs such as snacks, pocket money and once in a while new clothes.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: increase working capital

loans.name: Kitoola Womens Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
With benefit of hindsight, 29-year-old N. Harriet carried early firm conviction that she could not fail in her first business endeavour. She felt she owed it to herself not to falter like many of her colleagues had, trying to take root in business. Just like her father who battled all odds to succeed in business, she had to blaze her own trail and true to her word she did.

It is ten years down the road since she began her beauty salon business in Kitoola, Lugazi. She and her family have been basking in the glow of this business since then. Downsides have been there in her business but she has managed to nip them in the bud with the assistance of friends.

Harriet’s well-rounded experience has helped her a great deal as she plans and consolidates for the future. All her five children are now in school. She is also happily married to her husband of seven years.

In a month, Harriet says she earns to the tune of 200,000 shillings and is anticipating a scenario where she will be able to significantly improve on her business operations. With this loan, she is very upbeat that she will be able to bring some of her plans to bear. She wants to buy new salon equipment with the loan.

loans.use: To buy new salon equipment like hairdryers, shavers and weavers

loans.name: Jose Luis

texts.es:
José Luís es Chofer asalariado de trufi 5 Sindicato Eduardo Abaroa. Esta es su principal fuente de ingreso con  que cubre la manutención de su familia. Vive en la zona  Vino Tinto de la ciudad de La Paz.
 
El préstamo lo destinará a la compra de material de construcción para la reparación de una de sus habitaciones de sus hijas.
 
Es tercer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada califica para el préstamo solicitado por José Luís.
texts.en:
José Luís is a salaried driver of a minibus in 5 Union Eduardo Abaroa. This is his principal source of income, with which he covers the expenses of his family. He lives in the zone Vino Tinto (“Red Wine”) in the city of La Paz. This loan will be used in the purchase of construction materials for the repair of one his daughters' rooms. This is his third loan with Impro, the evaluation qualified him for the loan he is asking for.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy materials to repair the room of José Luís' daughter

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan is a driver in the small township of Masindi, Uganda. He is married to a teacher and together they have three children aged seven, five, and three years. He has a vehicle which he uses in his transport business and he has operated it for five years now. He says you need to be a hard-working person to succeed in the transport business in Uganda, especially with small vehicles like Hassan’s. 

Hassan has, however, been able to build his own house from the profit from the business and he hopes to buy a new good vehicle in future for his transport business. For now though, he wants to use the loan funds to buy a second-hand vehicle for his transport business.

loans.use: buying a second-hand vehicle for his transport business

loans.name: Violet

texts.en:
Violet is a 47-year-old single mother to three children aged 26, 23 and 22. The eldest is now at university and she says it’s been a struggle reaching there. She dreams of educating all of them so that they can be helpful to themselves in their adulthood. 

Violet operates a bar in Masindi, Uganda which also has a takeaway services. She has been in the bar business for 10 years now and though it, she has been able to build her own house.

After the children complete school, Violet says she will be able to transform the bar business into a modern one with better facilities. The purpose of the loan is to pay tuition fees for her eldest son at university.

loans.use: paying tuition fees for her eldest son at university

loans.name: Ainea

texts.en:
Ainea Angweke L. is 34 years old, married and has three children, whom he hopes to give the highest level of education. His business is located in Kakamega. He has been selling spades, padlocks, slashers, trowels and other tools to the local people. He has been doing this business for ten years now. He says that this business is profitable and his major challenge is financial constraints. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. 

Ainea is using his loan of 80,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more hardware equipment to expand his business. He hopes to be a big businessman and catch a big target market. He is very hardworking, patient and ambitious.

loans.use: To buy spades, slashers and  padlocks

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.fr: Monsieur Mamadou D. est un commerçant de 29 ans. Il habite à Sangalkam, une localité avoisinante de la zone de Bambilor. Il est membre de la caisse de Bambilor depuis janvier 2010. Il est marie sans enfants. Il gère une boutique depuis 2002 et s’adonne a la vente de marchandises diverses. C’est une activité  qu’il a hérité  de sa famille et a longtemps pratique l’apprentissage avant d’ouvrir sa propre boutique.  Ce qui l’intéresse le plus dans son activité c’est l’aspect lucratif grâce auquel il parvient a satisfaire ses besoins personnels. Monsieur D. sollicite un crédit de 400 000 frs car il envisage d’ouvrir une deuxième boutique non loin de la première.  Le crédit lui permet a chaque fois d’améliorer  ses profits et de prendre en charge la nourriture et les frais médicaux  de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Mamadou D. is a 29-year-old merchant. He lives in Sangalkam, a locality in the Bambilor area. He has been a member of the Bambilor branch of U-IMCEC since January 2010, and is married without children. Since 2002 he operates a store where he sells various types of merchandise. He learned this activity from his family and was an apprentice for a long time before opening his own store. What attracts him most in this activity are the financial returns thanks to which he can satisfy his personal needs. Mr. D. is requesting a loan for 400,000 francs so that he can open a second store not far from the first. The credit loans enable him to increase his earnings and cover his family’s food and healthcare needs.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: investment

loans.name: Katumpe Ole

texts.en:
Katumpe Ole N. is 28 years old. He is married to Norparko N. and he is a father of two school-going children. Katumpe is a farmer and he has been doing this work for the last six years. His farm is in a productive area which has proved to be good for wheat farming.

He learned about KADET from a colleague who is already a Kadet-registered client. This will be his second loan with which he is planning to plant more wheat. He hopes to use the profit from this loan to acquire more land for farming to meet the demand for wheat produce.

His hope and dream is to become a large-scale farmer and have his own farm machinery. Katumpe is a young and energetic man who can do more if supported financially.

loans.use: To plough the land for wheat planting

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
