loans.use: To purchase spare parts for repairing his car

loans.name: Ousmane

texts.fr: Monsieur Ousmane D. est un jeune couturier de 32 ans qui habite à Guediawaye. Il est membre de la caisse de CSP depuis 2005. Il a déjà rembourse 2 crédits antérieurs. Il est célibataire sans enfants. Depuis 7 ans déjà Monsieur D. évolue dans la couture et la vente d’habits confectionnes ou de prêt a porter. C’est un métier  qu’il a hérité  de son de père. Il emprunte 150 000 frs prévu  pour l’achat de tissus utilises pour la confection de ses habits  à vendre. L’objectif vise par Monsieur D. est de satisfaire sa clientèle dakaroise et gabonaise. Le crédit l’aide à soutenir son père et sa mère  dans la gestion des dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
Mr Ousmane D. is a young tailor who is 32 years old and lives in Guediawaye. He has been a member of the CSP savings bank since 2005. He has already repaid two previous loans. He is single and has no children. For the past seven years Mr. D. has been developing his tailoring activity and selling custom made or ready-to-wear clothes. He inherited this trade from his father. he is borrowing 150,000 francs in order to buy fabric to make up the clothes that he will sell. The aim of Mr. D. is to satisfy his customers from Dakar and Gabon. The loan will help him to support his father and mother in the management of the family expenses.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investment

loans.name: Assan

texts.fr:
Madame Assan  H. est âgée de 33 ans, mariée et mère de 3 enfants.  Elle  vit  dans une famille nucléaire avec son mari et ses enfants au quartier Darsalam de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fait l’école, issue d’une famille de commerçants, elle commença très tôt les activités génératrices de revenus auprès de sa mère qui vendait des habits et chaussures. 
Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage auprès  de cette dernière,   elle a compris et assimilé les rouages du commerce qu’elle mène seule depuis 10 ans. Elle jouit d’une grande clientèle et notoriété. 
Dans le dessein d’augmenter son fonds de commerce pour faire face à la demande clientèle, elle a  fait recours à   Soro Yiriwaso, elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 60 mois. Après 4 prêts solidaires et 3 prêts  individuels tous  bien remboursés, elle est à son 4ème prêt individuel.
Elle compte utiliser  ce prêt pour acheter, 10 pièces  de pagnes wax, 5 pagnes de pagnes brodés et 2  pièces de bazins riches.  Elle s’approvisionne  sur place auprès des grossistes.
Madame  Assan  H. vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elle envisage de  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel 60 000 FCFA, ce dernier lui permet de consolider son fonds de commerce. 
Son ambition est  de construire une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mrs. Assan H. is 33 years old, married and mother to three children. She lives in a nuclear family with her husband and children in the Darsalam district of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having never been to school and coming from a family of traders, she began her revenue generating activities at an early age with her mother, who sold clothes and shoes. After several years as an apprentice with her mother, she understood and was able to assimilate the mechanics of the business, which she has now been running alone for ten years. She enjoys a large customer base and a good reputation. With a view to increasing her business in order to meet customer demand, she turned to Soro Yiriwaso and has had relations with this institution for the past 60 months. After four group loans and three individual loans, all of which have been repaid on time, she is on her fourth individual loan. She is planning on using this loan to buy ten pieces of "pagnes-wax" (highly decorative and colourful West African fabric), five pieces of embroidered "pagnes" and two pieces of rich damask fabric. She gets her supplies locally from wholesalers. Mrs. Assan H. sells for cash and on credit to a customer base made up of women and men. She envisages making a monthly profit of 60,000FCFA, which will allow her to consolidate her business. Her ambition is to build a house to live in.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabric

loans.name: United Family Group

texts.en:
Wesseh T. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called United Family.  He is 38 years old, single, and has three children who range from 8 to 1 and a half years old.  Wesseh was unable to attend school due to poverty.

For three years, Wesseh has been selling torchlights and batteries.  His business is located on Broad Street in downtown Monrovia, Liberia. He started his business with 1,800 Liberian dollars and now has an operating capital of 8,000 Liberian dollars. He says that customers get attracted to his business because of the quality goods he offers. 

Wesseh's dream is to move from selling on the street into a big shop in the future.  He plans to use his 9,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 45,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more torchlights and batteries for his business.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Wesseh is the one holding the sign.

loans.use: To buy more torchlights and batteries.

loans.name: Janet Achieng

texts.en:
Janet O. is a 23-year-old married mother of three children. As a way of helping her husband in taking care of the family, Janet started selling cereals in 2008 which later gave birth to a clothing business.

Janet lives in Manyatta, Kisumu, and travels all the way to Nairobi to purchase clothes that she later sells in Kisumu. As for the cereals, she purchases them in the nearby Kibuye Market where she also happens to operate her business.

Janet admits that operating two businesses is not easy because a lot of time and resources are needed. She is working hard to ensure that she manages to achieve her dream of buying a piece of land where she will be able to build rental houses.

Because of her inadequate knowledge of business operation, Janet decided to join K-MET to learn ways of improving her business. It is there that she came to learn about Kiva loans and decided to request Ksh 20,000 so that she will be able to restock her business and hence expand it.

loans.use: To increase her stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Danaya sont toutes mariées dans des familles polygames. Elles ont 40 ans,  4 enfants et habitent dans le village de Massala : Commune Rurale de Sakoïba   (4ème Région administrative du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de mariage et de voisinage. 
Dans le souci d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, elles ont  décidé d’adhérer au programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. 
Elles sont à leur 1er  de prêt solidaire et font le commerce, de bois de chauffe, d’arachide et de céréales (mil et riz). 
Madame Assoumahou T. qui est la présidente du groupe fait le commerce d’arachide et compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 2 sacs de grains d’arachide dans la foire de N’Gassola et Téssérèla.  Elle revend son  arachide à domicile et à la foire de Ségou à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant et à crédit. 
Comme toutes les autres femmes du groupe, Madame  Assoumahou T. espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 25.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour l’entretien des enfants et réinvestir dans leurs activités. 
Elles ont pour ambition d’aider leurs maris à assurer l’auto suffisance alimentaire dans leurs foyers respectifs.
texts.en:
The members of the Danaya group are all married and living in polygamous families. They average 40 years of age with four children and live in the village of Massala in the rural community of Sakoïba (fourth administrative region of Mali). They got to know each other through relatives, marriage and neighbors. As they want to expand their businesses, they decided to join Soro Yiriwaso's loan program. They are on their first group loan and trade in firewood, peanuts and cereals (millet and rice). Mrs. Assoumahou T., who is the president of the group, trades in peanuts and is planning on using her loan to buy two sacks of peanut grains at the fairs in N'Gassola and Téssérèla. She resells her peanuts at home and at the Ségou fair to a customer base made up of men and women, for cash and on credit. In common with all the other women in the group, Mrs. Assoumahou T. hopes to make an average monthly profit of 25,000FCFA, which will be used for the upkeep of the children and for reinvestment in their businesses. Their ambition is to be able to help their husbands to ensure self-sufficiency in terms of food in their respective households.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase peanuts

loans.name: Joel

texts.en:
Joel is 29 years old and married with four children between 1½  and 10 years old. Three of the children are attending school. Joel is practicing mixed farming in western Kenya near Litein town. He has been in this business for six years with only one employee. He sells his milk and tea to Kenya Tea Development Agency and the local market, respectively. He relies solely on this business to provide for his family.

He has requested this loan through Juhudi Kilimo for Kshs. 35,000 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He believes that the income he will get from the sale of milk will enable him to pay fees and provide enough milk for his family. He says that the main challenge he is facing right now is lack of enough market for his milk. In the future, he hopes to acquire a hybrid cow, which can produce more than 30 liters a day.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is a 26-year-old hardworking lady.  She does tailoring and makes cardigans.  She also grows vegetables for sale and operates a retail shop to earn a living.  She belongs to a group in Faulu Kenya where she saves her money on a weekly basis. She has been guaranteed a loan of Kes.80,000 from Faulu Kenya by the group members. She will use the loan to buy knitting thread, a dairy cow and maize flour for her shop.  Faulu has taught her how to manage business finances, which is why she is able to save her money on a weekly basis with the group.  She hopes to expand her business and become financially stable in the future.

loans.use: To buy knitting thread, a dairy cow and maize flour

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is a 35-year-old father of three. He has a retail shop where he sells maize flour, rice, soap, sugar and cooking fat and has been in this business for three years. He also does construction on a contract basis to earn more income to support his family since he is the breadwinner. He uses part of his income to pay fees for his children.

James is a new member of Faulu Kenya in a group called Destiny which was introduced to him by his friends. He joined the group so as to access loans easily from Faulu Kenya. He has requested a loan of Kes 50,000 to add to his stock of rice, maize flour, soap and cooking fat. He hopes to expand his shop into a wholesale business in the future.

loans.use: To buy more rice, maize flour, soap and cooking fat

loans.name: Djiguissèmè Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Djiguissèmè sont toutes mariées dans des familles polygames. Elles ont en moyenne 39 ans, 2 enfants et vivent  dans le même village de Massala dans la commune rurale de Sakoïba (4ème Région administrative du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage et de parenté. 
Les membres du groupe font le commerce de bois de chauffe, de mil, d’igname (tels Awa C.), de la farine de blé, de maïs  et de mil. 
Dans le souci  d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, elles ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso  et sont à leur 3ème  prêt solidaire.
Madame Awa C.  compte acheter avec son  prêt,  20 sacs d’igname au grand marché de Ségou. Elle se ravitaille généralement dans le village de Togo. L’igname est revendue au comptant et à crédit, sur place au village et en ambulant dans les villages voisins à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Madame  Awa C.  espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 30 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour assurer les soins de santé des enfants et l’auto suffisance alimentaire dans le foyer.
texts.en:
The women of the Djiguissèmè group are all married and living in polygamous families. They average 39 years of age and two children and all live in the same village of Massala, in the rural community of Sakoïba (the fourth administrative region of Mali). They know each other through marriage and family ties. The group members sell heating wood, millet, “igname” [a type of yam], which is what Awa C. sells, wheat flour, and corn. They have decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso to be able to increase their business capital, and are now on their third joint loan. Mrs. Awa C. plans to use her loan to purchase 20 bags of yams at the grand market of Ségou. She typically purchases her stock in the village of Togo. The yams are sold on cash and in credit, locally in the village or on the streets of neighboring villages, to a customer base composed of both women and men. Mrs. Awa Coulibay hopes to achieve an average monthly income of 30,000 West African Francs, which will be used to cover healthcare expenses for her children as well as allow the household to become self-sufficient in terms of food supply.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing yams [for resale]

loans.name: Susan Adhiambo

texts.en:
Susan Adhiambo is a vegetable vendor who lives in Manyatta and operates her business from Kibuye Market in Kisumu.

After finishing school and getting married, Susan decided to start her business in 2008 to be able to generate income and support her husband in supporting the family. She is 26 years old and the mother of three children. Her dream is to see her business expand and her children get a good education.

To boost her business, Susan requested a loan of Ksh 10,000.

loans.use: To increase her stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is 50 years old and is married with two children. He has been doing metalwork for ten years. He also operates a hardware shop and was previously farming.

Daniel is a member of Neema Gitiga Group, under Faulu Kenya, whose members support each other as entrepreneurs. The members of the group share business ideas, save their money on a weekly basis and guarantee each other’s loans. Since he joined the group, his living standards have improved.

Daniel has requested a loan of Kes 50,000 to buy scrap metals. He hopes to open up a workshop in the future.

loans.use: To buy scrap metals

loans.name: Rokia

texts.fr:
Rokia Traoré est âgée de 24 ans, célibataire et mère d’un enfant.  Elle  vit chez son père dans une famille traditionnelle au  quartier Pelengana Nord de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ayant abandonné  l’école en classe de 9ème  année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien) par suite de redoublements de classes, ainsi elle s’intéressa au commerce de condiments alimentaires  qu’elle mène au marché château de la ville de Ségou  depuis maintenant 3 ans. 
Dans le dessein d’augmenter son fonds de commerce pour faire face à la demande clientèle, elle  fait recours à   Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est à son 1er  prêt individuel  et compte l’utiliser   pour acheter 300kg d’oignons et divers autres colis de condiments. Elle s’approvisionne dans la zone office du Niger (Dougabougou, Séribala etc.). Madame Rokia Traoré vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée généralement  de femmes. 
Elle envisage de  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel 60 000 FCFA, ce dernier lui permet de subvenir à ses propres besoins du fait qu’elle est célibataire et mère d’un enfant et d’aider son père dans la prise en charge de certaines dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
Rokia Traoré, 24, is single and the mother of one child. She lives in her father's traditional household in the Pelengana Nord area of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having left school in the early grades of primary school (Malian education system) because she had had to repeat several grades, she became interested in selling condiments, which she has been doing in the Château market of the town of Ségou for three years now. Wishing to increase her working capital to satisfy her clientele, she came to Soro Yiriwaso. She is on her first individual loan and intends to use the money to buy 300 kg of onions and various other packets of condiments. She buys her inventory in the Office du Niger zone (Dougabougou, Séribala etc.) Madame Rokia Traoré sells for cash or credit to a clientele mostly made up of women. She hopes to make a monthly profit of 60,000 F CFA which will allow her to support herself since she is single and the mother of a child and to help her father cover certain family expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy onions and other condiments

loans.name: Dominic

texts.en:
Dominic is 36 years old and single. He operates a retail shop where he sells household goods and he also does farming to earn extra income.

Dominic is a member of Ushindi Group, in Faulu Kenya, whose group members previously supported him by being his guarantors when he took out a loan of Kes 20,000.  He has requested a new loan of Kes 40,000 to buy buckets, basins and plastic water tanks.

In the future Dominic hopes to buy a lorry (truck) for transporting his goods.

loans.use: To buy buckets, basins and plastic water tanks

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is 33 years old and married with five children aged between 1½ years and 15 years. Four of the children are in school.

Joyce is a farmer in North Rift, Kenya, near Litein town. She has been in this business for fifteen years selling her milk, tea and maize to the local market. She also employs two people to help her on the farm. She also earns some income from the sale of poultry.

Joyce has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for Ksh 45,000 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She hopes this loan will enable her to generate more income and enable her to educate her children. In the future she intends to buy land and install a maize-milling machine and construct a shop.

Joyce is grateful to Juhudi for the provision of a grace period, which allows her to pay only interest for two months, because if she purchases a cow that is already inseminated then that will ease the payments for this loan.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is 31 years old and married with one child. He runs a retail shop where he sells general merchandise such rice, sugar, flour and cooking fat to earn a living. Moses is a very hardworking man who also sells clothes to earn enough money to support his family since the living costs are high. He was previously selling electronics before he ventured into this business.

Moses saves his money with a group in Faulu Kenya on a weekly basis which enables him to access loans because the group guarantees loans made to its members.

Moses hopes to grow his business to wholesale and open outlets in the future. He has requested a loan of Kes 40,000 from Faulu Kenya to add to his stock of sugar, rice, cooking fat and cereals.

loans.use: To add to his stock of sugar, rice, cooking fat and cereals

loans.name: Assanatou

texts.fr:
Madame  Assanatou    D.  est âgée de 43 ans,  mariée et mère de 7 enfants, elle vit dans une famille polygamique avec son mari, sa coépouse et leurs enfants au quartier Darsalam de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Assanatou a abandonné l’école en classe de 3ème année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien) pour faire le commerce auprès de sa mère qui vendait de l’arachide. Après plusieurs années passées à côté de cette dernière elle a pu maîtriser le commerce. Elle finit par évoluer seule, en menant le commerce d’articles divers tels la  vente de produits de beauté, le savon local, les chaussures etc. Elle jouit d’une grande clientèle et réputation qui dépasse le cadre de son quartier de résidence.
Dans l’intention de faire face à la demande clientèle,  elle a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est en relation depuis 54 mois et a déjà bénéficié de 5 prêts solidaires et 2 prêts individuels, tous remboursés sans difficulté. 
Elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel qui sera utilisé pour acheter, 250 paires de chaussures. Elle s’approvisionne au Togo.
Madame Cissé  Assanatou    D.  vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000 FCFA,  ce qui lui permettra de prendre certaines charges familiales surtout les dépenses des enfants. 
Son ambition est de faire l’embouche bovine comme son mari.
texts.en:
Madame Assanatou D., 43, is married and the mother of 7 children. She lives in a polygamous household together with her husband, her co-spouse, and their children, in the Darsalam district of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Assanatou left primary school in the third grade (Malian educational system) to work together with her mother who sold peanuts. After working with her for several years, Assanatou had mastered the art of commerce. She went out on her own, selling various items such as beauty products, local soap, shoes etc. She has a big clientele and a reputation that extends even beyond the area she lives in. In order to cater for her clientele, she came to Soro Yiriwaso with whom she has been working for 54 months. She has already had 5 solidarity loans and two individual loans, all reimbursed without difficulty. She is on her third individual loan which will be used to buy 250 pairs of shoes. She buys her inventory in Togo. Madame Cissé Assanatou D. sells for cash and credit to a clientele composed mostly of women. She expects to make a monthly profit of 150,000 F CFA which allows her to cover certain family expenses, especially those relative to their children. Her ambition is to raise cattle as her husband does.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying shoes for resale

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Thirty-year-old Daniel is the married father of three children aged between 1 year and 12 years, two of whom are in school.

Daniel has been practicing mixed farming in Litein town in the North Rift Valley of Kenya for ten years and has two employees who help him on the farm. He sells his tea, milk and maize to the local market. He owns a motorbike which also earns him some income from the transport services he offers to the locals. He was also an athlete before he ventured into farming.

Daniel has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for Ksh 45,000 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He believes that the sale of milk will increase his income and improve his family's health. His main challenge is the fluctuations in milk prices which makes it hard for him to budget on his income. He is asking the government to help stabilize milk prices in future so that farmers can realize a steady income.

In the future, Daniel intends to purchase a piece of land and improve the quality and size of his dairy farm. He also wants to buy a car for transportation.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a 28-year-old lady who is married to a teacher. She is blessed with two school-aged children.

Grace offers computer services such as photocopying, lamination and printing and sells stationery as well as refreshments. She has been running the business for four years and has one employee.

Grace is a member of Ushindi group in Faulu Kenya whose members guarantee each other’s loans. She has requested a loan of Kes 40,000 to buy photocopy paper and a printer cartridge.

Grace hopes to build her own house in the future. In five years, she wants to become a wholesaler. Grace describes herself as a hardworking lady.

loans.use: To buy photocopying paper and a printer cartridge

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is 30 years old and married with two children aged 4 years and 6 years. Both of the children are in school.

Lydia is a farmer in the North Rift Valley of Kenya near Litein town. She has been farming for ten years, selling her tea, milk and pineapples to the local market. She mainly depends on the income she gets from the sale of tea to provide for her family.

Lydia has requested her second loan from Juhudi Kilimo for Ksh 50,000 to purchase a dairy cow. She says that this loan will enable her to acquire a good dairy cow that will produce more milk and enable her to earn more income from the sale of milk. This income, she says, will improve her family's living standards.

In the future Lydia intends to expand her dairy farm by purchasing several dairy cows. She appreciates Juhudi Kilimo's initiative in targeting small-scale farmers since there was no such facility before.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Dolith Adhiambo

texts.en:
Dolith Adhiambo is a 23-year-old tailor who makes and sells clothes, a business she started in 2009 after completing her tailoring course.

With one year of experience, Dolith has been able to get quite a number of customers so that she ends up falling short of supplies. It is for this reason she decided to apply for a loan of Ksh 10,000 to be able to increase her stock and boost her business. This will enable her to achieve her dream of having her own business premises where she will no longer be paying rent.

Dolith is married, has three children. She and her family live in Manyatta, Kisumu.

loans.use: To add more stock to her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy is a 28-year-old single lady with a 2-year-old child. She has been selling clothes for five years in an open-air market to earn a living.

Since she joined Faulu Kenya, Mercy has been able to save her money with a group of friends who are also members of Faulu Kenya. She plans to add to her stock of children’s clothes and women’s clothes. For this reason, she has requested a loan of Kes 60,000 from Faulu Kenya.

Mercy hopes to expand her business into a wholesale operation in the future.

loans.use: To buy more children's and women's clothes to sell

loans.name: Mousa

texts.en:
M. is 28 years old, single, and lives in Chtoura, in the Bekaa. He is a mechanic and operates his garage where he repairs vehicles. He has been running this garage for the past year, but he rents it and doesn’t own it.

M. has gained experience in this field of work due to his previous job. He decided on opening his garage because of his experience and wanted to have independent work.

For the first time, M. has requested a loan to pay the rent of his garage. For the future, he plans to own his own garage and expand his business.

loans.use: To pay the rent of his garage

loans.name: Ngeno

texts.en:
Ngeno is 37 years old and married with four children between the ages of 16 and 27 years old. Four of the children are still attending school. Ngeno is a hardworking farmer from the North Rift Valley of Kenya near Litein town. He has been in this business for fifteen years and has two employees. Ngeno sells his milk to the Kenya Cooperative Creameries. He also earns some income from a posho mill (which grinds grain into flour) and a butchery he operates in the same area. 

He has requested this second loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 80,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow. Ngeno's main challenges are transporting the milk to the market and the constant fluctuations in the prices of milk. He says that this loan will enable him get a good dairy cow that will produce more milk and enable him to earn more income. This income will enable him educate his children and repay the loan. In the future he hopes to acquire a large piece of land, and expand his dairy farming.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more rice, flour and cooking oil.

loans.name: Jeniffer

texts.en:
Jenniffer is 52 years old and married with four children who are in school.  She sells household utensils in her shop to earn a living.  She has been in the business for four years and has one employee.  She saves her money with her group in Faulu Kenya which enables her to access loans because the group guarantees loans. 

She had previously taken out a loan of 20,000 KES from Faulu Kenya which she used to expand her business and she successfully repaid.  She has a good customer base because of her good customer care skills.  She hopes to grow her business into a supermarket in the future. She has requested a loan of 40,000 KES from Faulu Kenya to add to her stock of utensils for sale.

loans.use: To add to her stock of utensils.

loans.name: Jony

texts.en:
Jony is a 43-year-old married man and the father of two children. He and his family live in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon. Jony works on a freelance basis as a home painter, upon request of clients.  He learned the business when he was a 19-year-old teenager, which means he started working in 1986. He works hard to satisfy the demands of his job in order to pay his daily expenses and provide a better life for his family. He has gained lots of experience, and has a good network since he is known for his good and talented work. 

This is the first time that he has requested a loan from Al Majmoua. This loan will allow him to purchase new and better tools for his business. For the future, he plans to continue to improve his work which will benefit his financial situation.

loans.use: To purchase paint and tools for his work.

loans.name: Raniah

texts.en:
Raniah is a 34-year-old single mother of two children who got divorced a few years ago. Since then she has been doing her best to improve her living and financial situation, but more importantly to depend upon herself. 

She decided to open a child care in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, where she takes care of children when they come to spend the day, play, sleep, eat and do many activities. Raniah is very devoted to her work. She said that she loves the children as if they were her own kids. She decided to open her child care because she learned about it at school and used to work as a kindergarten teacher.

Today, for the first time, she asked for a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase educational toys for the children, as well as to add new decorations.  In the future, she plans to keep on improving her child care as well as her financial situation.

loans.use: To purchase educational toys for children.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is 32 years old and married with one child who is three years old. He grows vegetables and cereals on his farm to earn a living. He has been in the business for thirteen years and has three employees.

Moses saves his money on a weekly basis with his group in Faulu Kenya which enables him to access loans which the group guarantees. He has previously taken out two loans from Faulu Kenya of Kes 60,000 which he used to expand his business and which he successfully repaid.

Moses hopes to grow his business to large-scale farming and improve his living standards in the future. He has requested a loan of Kes 40,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy farm inputs and seedlings.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs and seedlings

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Irine Akoth

texts.en:
Irine Akoth M. started her fruit and vegetable vending business in 2004 and operates it in Kibuye Market in Kisumu. She buys her stock in Kibuye market on a daily basis.

Irine is married and has four children. She lives with her family in Manyatta, Kisumu. Before she started her business she used to be a housewife, depending on her husband for anything she needed. But that, to her, is long-gone history.

After joining K-MET to learn ways to develop her business, Irine became interested and applied for a Kiva loan of Ksh 10,000 to increase her stock. She is optimistic that she will be able to get lenders to loan her the money.

Irine wishes to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: To increase her stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en:
Pauline is 30 years old and married with two children who are in school. She sells cosmetics and also used clothing in Nairobi to earn a living. She has been in the business for two years and has one employee. She gets extra income from her husband who has really given her much support in her business.

Pauline is a hardworking lady who is willing to improve her living conditions. She has joined a group in Faulu Kenya where she saves part of her profits and she can access loans which the group guarantees. She has a good customer base because of her good customer care skills.

Pauline has requested a loan of Kes 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to add to her stock of cosmetics and used clothes. She hopes to grow her businesses to wholesale in the future.

loans.use: To add to her stock of cosmetics and used clothing

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Hilda

texts.en:
Hilda is 28 years old and married with two children who are in school. She runs a boutique in Nairobi where she sells bedcovers and ladies’ clothes and cosmetics to earn a living. She has been in the business for three years and has one employee. She receives extra money from her husband who has really supported her in the business.

Hilda’s business has really grown since she joined Faulu Kenya. She saves her money on a weekly basis with her group which guarantees loans to its members. She hopes to grow her business to a wholesale operation and improve her living standard in the future.

Hilda has requested for a loan of Kes 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to add to her stock of clothes and cosmetics.

loans.use: To add to her stock of clothes and cosmetics

loans.name: Dambé Group

texts.fr:
Dambé est un regroupement de femmes de Koutiala qui se connaissent bien car elles  vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 35 ans, sont mariées et mères d’au moins 5 enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels que, le  bois de chauffe, les céréales,  le beurre de karité et du sucre etc. 
 Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a  une année. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de groupe et le premier a été bien  remboursé. 
Mariam T. est un membre du groupe Dambé qui vend exclusivement du bois de chauffe.  
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des chargements de bois de chauffe en brousse. Elle se procure  du bois dans les différents coins de brousse auprès des paysans producteurs.  
Elle vend le bois en détail et au comptant à la maison devant la porte à une clientèle constituée en majorité de femmes. 
Tandis que les autres membres du groupe Dambé comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 60 000FCFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle, Mariam T. compte réaliser 70 000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille. 
Elles souhaitent voir renforcer ce partenariat avec  Soro Yiriwaso pour que les stocks ne soient pas rares.
texts.en:
Dambé is a group of women from Koutiala who know each other well because they live in big traditional families with their husbands, children, and other relatives. They are 35 on average, married, and the mothers of at least 5 children. This group of women sell various items such as firewood, cereals, shea butter, sugar, etc. So as to expand their businesses, they decided to join Soro Yiriwaso a year ago. They are on their second group loan and the first one was correctly reimbursed. Mariam T. is a member of the Dambé group who sells exclusively firewood. She intends to use her share of the loan to buy loads of firewood in the country. She gets her firewood in various areas from the peasants who cut it. She sells it retail and for cash at her house, outside the door, to a clientele composed mostly of women. Whereas the other members of the Dambé group each expect to make a monthly profit of 60,000 F CFA during the course of the loan, Mariam T. expects to make 70,000 F CFA. Besides reimbursing the loans, the women will use a part of their income for day-to-day family expenses. They hope to strengthen their cooperation with Soro Yiriwaso so that they will always have enough inventory.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of firewood

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline is 23 years old and married. She runs a pharmacy in her home town to earn a living. She has been in the business for two years and has one employee. She is a hardworking lady who also practices commercial farming to earn extra income.

Caroline is determined and focused to improve her living conditions now that she has joined a group in Faulu Kenya called Imani. She saves her money on a weekly basis with her group which guarantees loans to its members.

Caroline hopes to grow her pharmacy and also expand her farming business to large scale farming in the future. She has requested a loan of Kes 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to add to her stock of antibiotics.

Caroline is photoed with the husband in her pharmacy.

loans.use: To add stock of antibiotics

loans.name: Danaya ("confidence") Group

texts.fr:
Danaya est un regroupement de femmes de Koutiala qui se connaissent bien car elles  vivent ensemble dans le même quartier, dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et coépouses. Elles ont en moyenne 34 ans, sont mariées et mères d’au moins 3 enfants. 
Les membres du groupe Danaya font l’achat vente  de produits cosmétiques, d’habillements  d’ingrédients pour  la restauration et  le bois de chauffe.
 Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. 
Assétou Boiré  qui est un des membres fait l’achat et la vente des produits cosmétiques de toutes sortes (encens, pommade, parfums  etc.) En plus elle vend occasionnellement les parures, colliers bracelets et boucles d’oreilles.  Elle est très sollicitée. 
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une importante quantité de produits cosmétiques. Elle se procure de ces marchandises au  grand marché de Koutiala en gros pour les  revendre en détail et au comptant à une clientèle essentiellement féminine. 
Tandis que les autres membres du groupe Danaya comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 105 000FCFA chacune au  cours de ce cycle, Assétou Boiré  elle,  compte réaliser 120 000 FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Danaya is an association of Koutiala women who know one another well, since they live together in the same district, in large traditional families with their husbands, children, and co-wives.  Married, these women average 34 years of age and have at least three children each.  They buy and sell cosmetics, clothing, ingredients for food catering, and firewood.  To increase the size of their businesses, the members of the group decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso.  Assétou Boiré, who is one of the members of the group Danaya, buys and sells cosmetics of all sorts (incense, ointments, perfumes, etc.)  In addition, she occasionally sells fine accessories, necklaces, brackets, and earrings.  She is in high demand.  Assétou intends to use her loan for buying a sizable quantity of cosmetics.  She procures these goods wholesale at the big market of Koutiala, and then she sells them retail, accepting cash from a customer base essentially of women. While the other group members each plan on making an average profit of 105,000 francs CFA over the course of this cycle, Assétou herself plans on making 120,000 francs.  In addition to repaying these loans, the women are using part of the revenues for coping with typical family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cosmetic products

loans.name: Mofsis

texts.en:
Mofsis is a 53-year-old man who lives with his wife and three children in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon.

Mofsis operates a sewing business in his town. He started his sewing business two years ago and has worked hard over the years to gain experience and build a loyal customer base. In 2008, he began operating his own sewing shop.

For the first time, Mofsis is requesting a loan to purchase more materials and fabrics for his sewing business.

loans.use: To purchase more materials and fabrics for his sewing business

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is married with six children. Some of her children go to school and the rest are working. She rents a two-room house where she stays with eight people. She has one granddaughter. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Helen takes care of additional family members. Helen had an accident and can’t walk easily.  

The family gets three meals a day. Her monthly expenses include school fees, feeding the family and medication. Her husband is a peasant farmer in Naguru. Helen owns a retail shop selling sugar, beer and soap and works seven days a week. She rents the shop where she operates. Helen receives at least 10 customers a day and her customers are mainly women and children. She sells at retail. Besides this retail shop business, Helen also sells fried cassava chips and pancakes.  Helen has been in this business for some years and her business challenges include thieves, seasonality and competition. Helen has been with MCDT for many years, servicing her 11th loan.  She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of sugar, more bunches of sweet bananas and crates of beer. She hopes to see her business grow bigger, build her own house and educate her children up to the university level.

loans.use: To buy more sugar, sweet bananas and soap

loans.name: Martin

texts.en:
Martin is a hardworking and focused man who is married and blessed with two children who are in school.

Martin runs a butcher shop in his hometown to earn a living and has been in the business for five years. He is married to a business lady and, with the two businesses, they are able to support their family and pay school fees for their children.

Martin saves his money with his group in Faulu Kenya called Sinuka Kitengela which guarantees loans made to its members. He hopes to grow his business since he can access loans and this is his first loan. He has requested a loan of Kes 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to add to his stock of goats for slaughter.

Martin hopes to grow his business and open other outlets in the future.

loans.use: To add to his stock of goats for slaughter

loans.name: Jackline Wanja

texts.en:
Jackline is a 29-year-old single lady who lives in the Kayole area of Nairobi. She lives in an area that has very many mixed businesses with a high population of low-income earners.

Jackline operates a secondhand clothes business and this has been her source of income for the last two years.

Jackline has never borrowed from other financial institutions. With this loan she plans to add to her stock of secondhand cloths for resale. Her customers are mainly at a busy place in Dohnholm, next to the stage, and the flow of customers is good.

In the future, Jackline hopes to expand her business and open new outlets.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell, especially ladies' clothes

loans.name: Manal

texts.en:
Manal is a 28-year-old young married woman living with her husband and their three children in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon.

In order to help with her family’s expenses, Manal opened a beauty salon in a room of her home where she offers beauty services like hairdressing, make-up, hair removal and more to her clients. She has become well-known in her region and her clients feel comfortable coming to her.

With the loan she has requested, Manal plans to expand her home business by purchasing additional equipment and products; for example, she plans to buy new beauty products. She says that her business productivity and income will both increase as a result since she will be able to attract new clients.

loans.use: To purchasing additional equipment and products

loans.name: Poni

texts.en: Poni G. is currently in the business of selling maize flour and rice and is requesting a loan to stock bags of beans to sell. Poni is 48 years old and is widowed. She has two children and her children do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house and put it up for rent. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock bags of beans to sell

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad is a 50-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon. He is a father of four children.

Mohamad owns an accessory shop where he sells necklaces, bracelets, phone key ring, make-up, CDs, photocopies, toys and much more. He has been operating his shop for five years now, but has a lot of experience due to his previous work in this field.

Today, Mohamad is requesting a loan to improve his work and expand his stock which he hopes will help him improve his financial situation. This is the first time that he has requested a loan.

Mohamad is special in his work because he does it well and is known for being welcoming to his clients who are his friends and neighbors. He decided on doing his business because he wanted to have independent work also because of his previous experience. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties.

In the future, Mohamad plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise for his shop

loans.name: Khady

texts.fr: Madame khady N. est une aide de santé communautaire qui travaille dans un poste de santé à mbour à 70 km de Dakar .Pour combler son vide elle est obligée de préparer des beignets qu'elle doit vendre.Elle ne disposant de salaire au niveau du poste car le peu qu'elle gagne dépend du bénéfice réalisé par le poste de santé .elle est obligé de faire des crédits pour avoir des fonds et atteindre ses objectifs en tant que mère de famille
texts.en:
Ms. Khady N. is a community health aid who works in a health clinic in Mbour, about 70 km from Dakar.  To make ends meet, she is compelled to make beignets which she must sell.  She has no salary at the clinic because the little she earns depends on the profits made by the clinic.  She has to take out loans for funding and for attaining her goals as the mother of a family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Commerce

loans.name: Jihad

texts.en: Jihad, a 26-year-old who lives in Beirut, Lebanon with his wife and their child, has known how to cut hair perfectly since he was 20. Upon seeing that he did it very well, he decided to establish his own barber shop five years ago. In order to open his own shop, he received the help of his father, who has been very supportive. In the future he plans to expand his shop in order to accommodate more customers and earn more. Jihad is now requesting a loan to buy certain products and tools that he needs for his business. This is the first time that he has requested a loan and is happy for the opportunity Kiva lenders are giving him. For the future, he hopes that he can continue improving his business.

loans.use: To buy products and tools.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is 35 years old and married with two children.  She sells eggs in her rural home to earn a living. She has been in the business for three years.  Her customers are her neighbors and her friends who know about the business.  She rents out her residential houses to earn enough money to support her family since the living costs are high.  

Joyce has been saving her money with her group in Faulu Kenya called 'Precious' which enables her to access loans and the group guarantees. She is determined to improve her business now that she can access loans and this is her first loan. She has requested a loan of Kes 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to add stocks of eggs for sale.  She hopes to venture into other businesses and improve her living standard in the future.

loans.use: To add stocks of eggs for sale.

loans.name: Ibrahima

texts.fr: Monsieur Ibrahima N. est un ouvrier dans une usine de pêche à mbour mais il dispose un taxi clando qui va assurer ses dépenses quotidiennes . Le but du prêt est l'acquisition de piéces détachées pour sa voiture qui est rester en panne depuis un certain moment  et sans cela il lui est difficile de tenir les 3 repas quotidiens comme tout sénégalais
texts.en:
Mr. Ibrahima N. is a worker in a fish factory in Mbour, but he has an unregistered taxi that is going to ensure that his day-to-day expenses are covered.  The goal of the loan is to acquire spare parts for his car, which has been out of commission for a while.  Without it, he would have trouble having three meals a day, as do all Senegalese people.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repair work

loans.name: Tadayo

texts.en:
Tadayo E. is currently in the business of selling local Sudanese bread cooked by frying it in oil. She is requesting a loan to stock more baking flour.  Tadayo is 24 years old and is married to a husband who is a teacher. She has 2 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more baking flour

loans.name: Madina

texts.en: Madina is a married with six children and  four of her children go to school.  Her husband owns a hardware shop in Kalerwe, one of the city suburbs.  She rents a one-room house where she stays with seven people. The family has access to electricity but no piped water. Madina takes care of additional family members. Monthly expenses include rent for her residence, medication, school fees and feeding the family.  She owns a restaurant selling all types of food ranging from traditional to western food. She sells to all categories of people at retail and at wholesale. She works six days a week. She incurs transport costs to and from shopping in Kalerwe market on e of the city suburbs.  Madina receives at least 25 customers a day She has been in this business for five years. She has been with MCDT for a some years servicing her 11th loan.  She wants to use this loan partly to pay school fees and partly to buy bunches bananas, charcoal,beef, cassava potatoes for her restaurant. Her main customers are neighbouring men  from  garages and cyclists  . She aspiring of owning a permanent business premises and home. She joined MCDT because it was near her home and wanted to raise enough capital for her business.

loans.use: To buy  more bunches of bananas, cassava, potatoes and charcoal for her restaurant and partly  to pay  school fees for children

loans.name: Augustine

texts.en:
Augustine is a renowned pharmacist. His sense of duty and diligence at his work make him a successful person in the industry. He is single and business-minded. He spends most of his time in his pharmacy shop serving customers. He sells his customers assorted pharmaceutical drugs like pain killers, malaria drugs, antibiotics and stimulants; blood tonic etc. prescribed by medical doctors. He has operated this business for the past five years. He obtains his medicines from registered chemists and big pharmacy outlets in the capital city. 

Augustine dreams of converting his shop into a wholesale outlet and supplying medicines to communal pharmacy shops.  He plans to use the loan to purchase assorted medicines and drugs in bulk. He desires to save more money to rent a bigger shop in town.

loans.use: To purchase assorted pharmaceutical medicines

loans.name: Fozia

texts.en:
Fozia J. is currently in the business of selling dresses and bedsheets and is requesting a loan to stock pairs of trousers and sandals to sell.  Fozia is 22 years old and is divorced.   She has 4 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a supermarket.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock pairs of trousers and sandals to sell

loans.name: Moussa

texts.fr: Monsieur Moussa D. est un commerçant qui gére une boutique de vente de piéces détachées au niveau de la gare routière .c'est un habitué des crédits ce qui l'a permis aujourd'hui d'avoir sa propre boutique .Ainsi il sollicite ce prêt pour renforcer son activité génératrice de revenu pour pouvoir son foyer en bon père de famille et s'occuper de la scolarité de ses enfants
texts.en:
Mr. Moussa D. is a trader who runs a spare parts store at the bus station. He is used to credit which enabled him today to have his own store. He is thus requesting this loan in order to strengthen his income generating business to take care of his household as the good father of the family and also to take care of the educatiuon of his children.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sale of spare parts

loans.name: Geoffrey

texts.en:
Geoffrey does poultry farming and also operates a retail shop.  He uses his income to pay wages to his two employees.  He is a member of 'Winners Kitengela' group under Faulu Kenya. He joined this group so as to access loans easily from Faulu Kenya since its members guarantee each other's loans.  

Geoffrey wants to buy more chicks for his farm.  Therefore, he has requested a loan of Kes. 20,000 from Faulu Kenya.  He hopes to be the major supplier of chicken in his area of residence.  He sees himself registering his business as a company so he can seek orders from other institutions. Geoffrey is 32 years old, married and the father of one.

loans.use: To buy more chicks

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Buy products to resell.

loans.name: Raphael

texts.en:
Raphael is a 32-year-old single man.  He owns pool tables which he rents out to earn a living.  He realized that this business can be profitable since many people love playing pool in their leisure time. He has been in the business for three years.  

Raphael also sells water so as to be able to cover his personal expenses and also to support his family.   He was previously employed before he started his business.   He saves his money with his group in Faulu Kenya called 'Siahani' which guarantees loans for its members.   He hopes to expand his business and also he desires to own a vehicle for public transportation in the future. He has requested a loan of Kes 35,000 from Faulu Kenya to get another donkey for transporting water and also to buy another pool table.

loans.use: To add a pool table and buy another donkey

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Onesmus

texts.en:
Onesmus sells tomatoes wholesale for a living.  He has been in this business for two years.  His business is located in Nairobi West in an open-air market. He also owns a salon where he earns more income.  He belongs to 'Zawadi' group in Faulu Kenya whose members have guaranteed a loan of Kes. 50,000 for him to buy more tomatoes for sale.  

Onesmus believes that this loan will make a difference in his business because his aim is to satisfy his customer demand and get more output.  He hopes to become a prominent businessman in the future.  Onesmus describes himself as hard-working and determined.

loans.use: To buy tomatoes

loans.name: Vugukuri Group

texts.fr:
Monique H. est une commerçante âgée de 49 ans qui habite la Commune urbaine de Kanyosha en Mairie de Bujumbura. Elle a fait ses études jusqu’en 7e année des écoles secondaires.  Elle  achète des bananes pour en fabriquer du vin qu’elle vend  dans les banlieues de Kanyosha. C’est un métier qu’elle a toujours pratiqué bien même avant qu’elle ne reçoive le crédit de Turame.

Elle est mère de 7 enfants ; 4 filles et 3 garçons et 5 d’entre eux sont mariés tandis que les 2 autres étudient à l’école secondaire. Elle lutte pour que ses enfants puissent étudier et terminer avec succès mais aussi avoir chacun sa propre maison en ville afin qu’ils vivent aisément. 

Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour augmenter la quantité des bananes à acheter pour pouvoir accroitre la quantité de vin qu’elle revend aux clients. Elle a l’espoir d’avoir un grand bénéfice avec cette augmentation de son capital. Elle pourra ainsi résoudre certaines de ses difficultés  relatives aux dépenses quotidiennes et les frais de scolarisation de ses enfants.  

 Elle est une des membres du groupe « VUGUKURI  » et sont au 7e cycle.
texts.en:
Monique H., 30, is a businesswoman who lives in the township of Kanyosha in City Hall in Bujumbura. She made it through seventh grade. She buys bananas to make wine with and then sells the wine in the suburbs of Kanyosha. This is the business she has always done well at, even before she got a loan through Turame. Monique is the mother of seven children, four girls and three boys, and five of them are married, whereas two others attend secondary school. She struggles so that her children will be able to attend school and graduate with success, but also so that each will be able to have his own house in town and live comfortably. She is requesting the Kiva loan to buy more bananas and produce more wine to sell to her customers. She hopes that this increase in working capital will lead to a lot more profit. That way, she will be able to resolve certain of her difficulties with daily expenses and paying school fees for her children. She is one of the members of the « VUGUKURI » group; they are on their seventh loan.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy more bananas so as to produce more of the wine she sells to her customers

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a 31-year-old lady.  She has been selling cereals, fruit, and fruit salad for one year.  She joined 'Mazao Kiserian' group in Faulu Kenya whose aim is to guarantee its members' loans.  Through the group, Mary has learnt how to manage her business finances and she is able to save her money.  She has requested a loan of Kes. 20,000 to buy fruit and cereals for sale.  She hopes to open up a classic fruit and fresh juice shop in the future.  She sees herself being self-sustainable in the future.

loans.use: To add stock of cereals and fruit

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is a relations officer at one of the best primary schools in Hoima, Uganda. As a salary earner, his income is fixed, irrespective of what he achieves at work, thus his need to have a side income, he says. He says for now, his biggest priority is education for the children, after which he hopes to own a personal car and enjoy life. His wife is a businesswoman and together they are now constructing rentals so as to earn extra income to sustain them. This is his first loan from HOFOKAM and he intends to buy iron sheets for his house which is under construction.

loans.use: buying iron sheets for his house

loans.name: Miguela

texts.es:
La Señora Miguela enviudo hace un año y medio, tiene dos hijas que estudian en la facultad y la ayudan en el negocio.
La señora siempre trabajó en el mercado en ventas y su marido era empleado publico.
Con mucho esfuerzo lograron montar un negocio propio dentro del mercado, actualmente cuentan con varios clientes generalmente empleados de los comercios vecinos.
Le gustaría que sus hijas terminen la universidad y que administren su propio negocio, como otro ingreso tiene alquilado un salón comercial en su domicilio.
Ella solicita el préstamo para la compra de panificados, aceite, harina, huevos, pantalones, remeras, camisas.
texts.en:
Sra. Miguela, who has been a widow for a year and a half, has two daughters in college who help her with her business. Miguela has long worked as a merchant in a local merchant and her husband was a public employee. After a lot of hard work, they managed to set up a business inside the market and she now has many customers, most of whom are employees of various businesses in the neighborhood. She would like her daughters to finish college and set up their own businesses. She also earns extra money renting out a salon in her house. She will use the loan to buy baked goods, cooking oil, flour, eggs, shirts, t-shirts and trousers.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products to resell

loans.name: Adrian

texts.es: EL SR. ADRIAN ESTA CASADO TIENE UN HIJITA PEQUEÑA, SE DEDICA AL TRANSPORTE YA HACE APROXIMADAMENTE 8 AÑOS INICIALMENTE COMENZO COMO AYUDANTE DE CHOFER, LUEGO CHOFER DE OCASIÓN LUEGO PASO A SER CHOFER ASALARIADO DURANTE 6 AÑOS, TIEMPO DURANTE EL CUAL PUDO AHORRAR DINERO PARA COMPRARSE UN VEHICULO PROPIO, EL CUAL EN ESTE MOMENTO NECESITA UNA REPARACION Y MANTENIMIENTO ES PARA ELLO QUE EL NECESITA ESTE CREDITO, SU ESPOSA SE DEDICA A LABORES DE CASA, EL SOLO  MANTIENE EL HOGAR RAZON POR LA CUAL TRABAJA TODO EL DIA, VIVE EN CASA EN ALQUILER Y UNO DE SUS DESEOS ES EL DE COMPRARSE UNA CASITA Y PODER IR A VIVIR CON TODA SU FAMILIA, ES UNA PERSONA RESPONSABLE Y DINAMICA ESTA MUY AGRADECIDA CON EMPRENDR Y KIVA POR LA CONFIANZA BRINDADA EN LA OTORGACION DEL CREDITO.
texts.en:
Adrian is married and has a young daughter. He has been working in transportation for some 8 years. He began as a driver's helper, then as a part-time driver, and for the last 6 years he has worked as a full-time salaried driver. During these 6 years he saved up to buy his own vehicle, which now needs to be repaired and maintained. This is why he needs the loan. Adrian's wife works at home, and since Adrian's salary is the only source of income for the household he works all day long. They currently live in a rented house and one of Adrian's dreams is to buy a little house where his family could live. He is a responsible and energetic person and is very thankful to Kiva and Emprender [the Kiva field partner] for the confidence they have placed in him by granting him the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Catherine Fountain, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Vehicle repair

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia is 46 years old and widowed with three children aged 25, 22, and 19.   She sells cereals and legumes, retail and wholesale, in an open-air market to earn a living. She also practices farming and green grocery businesses to earn extra income.  She has an experience of ten years in the business.   

Since she joined Faulu Kenya, Cecilia's lifestyle has improved because she can access loans.  She saves her money on a weekly basis with her group under Faulu Kenya which guarantees members' loans.  She has requested a loan of Kes 30,000 from Faulu Kenya to add stock of maize, beans and other types of cereals.  She hopes to open a store and a posho (maize meal) mill in the future.

loans.use: To add to her stock of cereals

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is a married with two children and her children go to school.  Her man is profession is a carpenter. She rents a one-room house where she stays with seven people. The family has access to electricity but no piped water. Margaret takes care of additional family members. Monthly expenses include rent for her residence, medication, school fees and feeding the family.  She owns a store at her home selling charcoal and sells to all categories of people  on  retail.  She works seven days a week.  Margaret receives at least 25 customers a day and has been in this business for 12 years and her business challenge is the rainy season because she works from a flooded place. She has been with MCDT for a few years, servicing her sixth loan.  She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of charcoal. Her main customers are neighbouring families. She aspires to own a permanent home.Margart joined MCDT because it was near her home and was charging low interest compared to other MFIs in the area.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en:
Sophia is a mother of two.  For seven years, she has been selling cereals and also runs a posho (maize meal) mill.  Besides, she is a dairy farmer.  She was previously selling clothes.  She is a member of a group under Faulu Kenya where she saves her money weekly.  The group members previously gave her support when she took out a loan from Faulu Kenya because they guaranteed her the loan.  

Sophia has requested a loan of Kes.80,000 to buy more cereals for sale.  Sophia is a hard-working lady who hopes to own a maize and wheat mill in the future.  She dreams of extending her market niche in five years.

loans.use: To add to her stock of cereals

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is a mother of three children. She is a teacher, tutor and also a businesswoman dealing in second-hand clothing. She lives in a town called Hoima, Uganda. Sarah is the breadwinner for a family of nine people and her family lives in a house Sarah constructed through her hard work. She dreams of seeing all her children educated to university level and that would make her very happy. 

When Sarah is not at school, she is busy selling second-hand clothing on market days. Second-hand clothing has a big market in Uganda because it is nice and affordable, according to consumers. So Sarah is busy on any day you meet her as she tries to earn income for the family’s welfare. She intends to use the loan funds to purchase second-hand clothing for selling.

loans.use: purchasing second-hand clothing for selling

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice S., from the village of Tumapagon, Cagayan de Oro City, is 30 years old, married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Alice owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Alice joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to to purchase additional products to sell, she is now requesting a new loan, her fifth, of 17,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. Alice plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Serafina

texts.es:
La señora Serafina Dominguez de 33 años empezó hace 4 años su negocio de confección de  ropa interior y gracias a la buena aceptación que tiene su producción hace 1 año pudo aumentar vendiendo también articulos de mercerías y roperías, es importante mencionar que el padre de su hijos tambien trabajo y a ayuda para la familia lleve una vida digna.

Desea incrementar sus ingresos invirtiendo en compra de telas para la confección de ropa interior, remeras, pantalones, short, sandalias, championes y otros articulos varios, que le permitirá ofrecer variedad a sus clientes, para este fin solicita el prétamos y agrdece a la Fundacion Paraguaya Y KIVA por la ayuda crediticia que la da mucha gente de escasos recursos.
texts.en:
Serafina Dominguez is 33 years old. Four years ago, she began a business sewing underwear and thanks to her great success in production, one year ago, she was able to expand to selling other clothing articles and notions. It’s important to mention that the father of her children also works and supports the family in a decent life.

She wants to increase her income, investing in the purchase of fabrics to sew underwear, as well as tee shirts, pants, shorts, sandals, tennis shoes, and other various articles, which will permit her to offer a variety to her customers. For this goal, she asks for the loans and thanks the Fundacion Paraguaya and KIVA for the financial support that they give to many people with scarce resources.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To acquire fabric to make underwear; to purchase shirts, teeshirts, tennis shoes and sandals

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To add to the stock of cereals in his wife's business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a hard-working businesswoman who sells a variety of cosmetics to her customers. She is a forty-nine-year-old widow and mother of six children. She spends most of her time taking care of her business and supporting her children in school. She loves selling and enjoys serving customers. She trades in make-up, hair pomades, hair bands and clips as well as bracelets and watches. She has operated her business for over 20 years in the central market of Kumasi. Mary believes in customer care and her broad smile almost always draw customers to her shop, making her one of the most successful traders in this product line. 

Mary deposits money with suppliers in the capital city to be supplied with stock almost every month to enable her to cut down on frequent travel to fill the demand. She hopes to receive the loan to purchase more stock to serve her customers. Mary is optimistic about the future and she hopes soon to acquire another store location at a different market in order to make more money to better support her family.

loans.use: To purchase assorted cosmetics, etc.

loans.name: Milly

texts.en: Milly is married with three children and her children go to school. She rents a one-room house where she stays with seven people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Milly takes care of additional family members. Monthly expenses include rent for her residence, medication, school fees and feeding the family.  She makes sweaters, tablecloths, cardigans and other items and sells to all categories of people at retail. She works seven days a week.  Milly works from her home and also does some tailoring work upon request. Milly receives at least five customers a day. She has been in this business for five years and her business challenge is transportation.  She has been with MCDT for a few years, servicing her third loan.  She wants to use this loan to buy more threads and needles for making sweaters. Her main customers are schools and neighboring families. She aspires to open a shop in Kampala to get more customers in town. She joined MCDT because it was near her home and was giving money to enterprising women.

loans.use: To buy more threads and needles

loans.name: Karole

texts.en: Karole is a 43-year-old man living in Hoima, Uganda. He is a father to seven children for whom he is responsible for school fees and welfare. He has a lorry which he uses in his transport business and has been in the business for 15 years now, having started as a mechanic. He says the current vehicle he has is old, meaning he is always in and out of the garage, but he hopes to buy a new one in the near future. This is his fourth loan from HOFOKAM and he intends to use the loan funds to buy new tires and repair the vehicle's engine.

loans.use: buying new tires and repairing the vehicle's engine
